name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda was the debate on the report by Pavel Telička, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the aviation strategy in Europe (2016/2062 (INI)) (A8-0021 / 2017)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in the recent past we have not had that many opportunities to praise the European Union for something very concrete and tangible but I must say that the aviation sector has been a success, and it has been a success thanks to the European Union. Imagine air transport twenty years ago, and the possibilities and opportunities for consumers, for us travellers; I think that flying away for a weekend somewhere in Europe at low cost was difficult to imagine. In fact, aviation at that time was for maybe a limited number of people. This is a concrete result of the Single European Sky and the liberalisation that we managed to pursue at European Union level.  Now, increased aviation transport does not mean that we do not face any challenges. In fact, I could name at least some of them: environmental targets, certainly. I do not think anybody would deny today that we need to continue with lowering emissions from air transport. Competition with third countries, digitalisation – it is now more than a year ago that the Commission came with its plan to address these and some other challenges. In fact, it proposed to start negotiations with our main partners, to revise the rules on the European Aviation Safety Agency, and tap EU potential for growth by revising some internal regulations. This is, of course, very welcome and we have already started working on some of it, but, at the same time, we still are still awaiting some of the proposals.  The aviation sector undoubtedly requires heavy investment in a fast-evolving environment. If we want to be efficient, then we need to set a clear vision for this sector, for the investments we make today and in the future. We need to have a vision for the next, even I would say, 50 years. This is, to a certain extent, the purpose of this report, to try to find some practical alternatives for what is not working today and to make some proposals for the future. I am afraid I cannot list all of them today, but at least allow me to make a few points.  First of all, develop a connectivity index based on added value of all modes of transport, in order to rationalise investment and improve the overall resilience of the transport network in Europe, while improving connectivity. This index can help policymakers to take the appropriate decisions without undermining territorial cohesion.  Secondly, a trans-European motorway of the sky, to limit the impact of possible disruptions to where they occur, thereby allowing EU flights to pursue their journey. This was the subject of a bit of a debate in meetings with some of my colleagues. I promised that I would make it clear to the Commission that this completely means that we are putting an EU stamp on a part of the airspace and saying that in this airspace the EU should have priority over national flights. I would like to stress that this is not against national sovereignty and it is not against the right to strike. On the contrary, this is only about recalling some obligations that we should have towards the European Union.  I will be very brief on the European Aviation model. We need to stop thinking that we will solve problems of competition with our partners by putting an end to competition. This is only going to be detrimental to passengers. Competition is an opportunity for our airlines. We need to provide them with the right safeguards, of course, and this is why the European Parliament will be following closely the negotiations on air agreements. I find intermodality a very important element of this report because quite often when we talk specifically about aviation as a transport mode, we tend to take it separately from other modes of transport.  Finally, on security, there is no need to recall why this is a major concern now. Of course, we need better coordination of EU intelligence and we should make sure we make the most up to date technology equipment, but we should also be careful not to overburden passengers. That is why the Commission is invited to consider the creation of an EU pre-check system where passengers could voluntarily register in order to go through smooth security checks once at the airport. There are many more [topics] in the draft aviation strategy and maybe we will have an opportunity to debate them today.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Sir. Chairman! I would like to thank my colleagues in both the Employment and Transport Committee for standing together in the fight for better conditions in European aviation. Better rules are needed here and now. The rules we have today simply do not work well enough. It is to the great detriment of both employees and the companies that behave properly. In the hunt for cheap tickets, we see a race to the bottom, against worse conditions, wages you can not live on, and an extreme creative use of the rules. The time has come to take responsibility and ensure proper conditions. No worker should be in doubt about in which country you have to pay tax and in which country you have your social security. We need to get rid of all creative forms of employment that try to circumvent this. With the adoption of this report, we in the European Parliament must stand together and press the Commission to come up with concrete proposals that can ensure fair competition and proper working conditions. We must act now, otherwise it looks bleak for the future of European aviation!

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Honourable Members for the opportunity to address them today and to exchange views on aviation matters. I welcome your own-initiative report, which provides a comprehensive view of the aviation sector.  I would like to thank Mr Telička and Mr Christensen for their hard work, as well as the other committees involved. Aviation clearly matters to our economy and citizens. We are talking about more than two million direct jobs and a direct contribution of EUR 110 billion to the EU economy. EU aviation today represents 26% of the world market. It therefore deserves all our attention.  It is clear that we have our work cut out – all actors, both at national and European level – so allow me to turn to the key points raised in your report. First, regarding the internal market, I fully support swift progress on the blocked aviation files. Each year around EUR 5 billion are wasted because we have not been making progress with the Single European Sky. I fully agree with your call for completing the EU single market for aviation. In this regard, the Commission will launch this year a feasibility study for the creation of a single European upper airspace to see how that could contribute concretely to the efficiency of our skies.  On foreign investment, the Commission welcomes your continued support and interest in the EU-level comprehensive aviation agreements. In line with our commitments, we will keep you fully informed at all stages of the negotiations. Related to the competitiveness of the EU aviation sector, I take note of the emphasis you put on attracting foreign investment. This is closely linked to the importance of having fair competition. We are currently working on new measures aimed to promote or safeguard regional and overall connectivity in Europe, as announced in the Aviation Strategy. These measures are expected in the spring and should include the following: first, new guidelines on ownership and control rules to bring clarity and facilitate their application; second, new guidelines on public service obligation; third, a proposal to replace Regulation No 868/2004 on unfair practices with more effective instruments, our objective being to present a credible instrument that will allow us to act effectively when EU air carriers are injured because of the discriminatory practices originating from third countries; and last, but not least, guidelines for ATM service continuity.  On the third topic, standards, let me first say a few words on safety. I am pleased to note your support for our proposal on the revision of the aviation safety basic regulation and in particular that EASA should be equipped with sufficient resources and staff. I look forward to a trialogue on this file, which should have started this Monday, and I sincerely hope that a new date will be agreed without further delay. A lot of progress has been made so far and I am confident that we will conclude this file under the Maltese Presidency.  On the environment issue, following ICAO’s landmark agreement, we are now focused on getting the global scheme up and running. We are serious about achieving carbon-neutral growth for aviation and we will provide technical and financial assistance to make it happen globally. Aviation is a global business and no country must be left behind. In its proposal adopted earlier this month, the Commission is proposing to continue with the current geographic scope of the EU emissions trading systems for aviation, covering flights between airports in the European economic area. This will ensure a level playing field and equal treatment for all airlines flying in Europe. On social issues, let me now touch upon the social policy elements of your report. As noted in our Aviation Strategy, aircrew face legal complex issues due to their high mobility. In May 2016 the Commission published guidelines to help pilots and cabin crews by clarifying the legal regime applicable to mobile workers. Furthermore, the EU Court of Justice is expected this year to provide interpretation of these matters, in particular as regards the home base of aircrews. We are evaluating the concept of whether this notion of principal place of business is still fit for purpose. This is part of our ongoing evaluation of the air service regulation and this work should be completed next year, as foreseen in the Aviation Strategy.  The Commission is committed to strengthening social dialogue in aviation. The Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee on Civil Aviation offers opportunities for the aviation social partners and the Commission to better assess and address together the social challenges of aviation. Moving on to safety, let me be clear that the same safety standards apply to everyone, regardless of their employment relationships. Safety is our top priority and EASA is continuously examining the safety aspects of emerging business models. We will continue to closely monitor developments in the market and take action where necessary. Social dialogue is essential. The Commission is active and works closely with social partners, the Member States and all stakeholders when addressing these matters.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - President! For my part, I also welcome the fact that the Commission's strategy for tackling the challenges facing the aviation sector seeks not only to increase competitiveness but also to ensure greater protection of passengers 'and workers' rights and higher safety and environmental standards, as the Commissioner has just said. . This is also in line with the opinion of the ENVI Committee that the aviation sector has an important role to play in mitigating environmental impacts. However, the sector has a lot to do in terms of developing new technologies and research and development. I would like to thank those who helped me to formulate the ENVI opinion as rapporteur. Finally, I must mention the role of the Member States. I urge that steps be taken to implement the Single European Sky agreement and to review the regulations on air passenger rights.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - In the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, we have firmly committed to better passenger protection. Today, passengers are all too often left in the dark when they encounter problems with their plane journey. Where can they file a complaint? Who can give them the most current information, and so on? We also believe that anyone who books an airplane trip offline and online should have the same rights and obligations. Misleading consumers by charging a final price that is very different from the price shown at the beginning should be out of the question. The safety aspect should also be included. We must focus on new control technologies and also on proportional penalties for non-compliance, which in turn contributes to a safer travel environment and shorter travel time. Finally, as rapporteur for IMCO, I am disappointed that more elements of our texts were not included. After all, we believe they are necessary in building a strong and comprehensive aviation strategy.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, at the outset I would like to thank Mr Telička on behalf of the PPE members in the Committee on Transport and Tourism for his good work in facilitating our views and preparing this report. As we look back over the last 20-30 years and look at the benefits of liberalisation and single skies in our airspace and what that has meant for businesses, for jobs, for tourism, connecting people, regions and cities – that was bold, that was ambitious and that has led to the growth of low-cost airlines connecting people across Europe. Now we need the next tranche, the next wave of ambition. The aviation agreements are urgent and they need to progress, and I think this was outlined clearly in the committee’s report.  Europe is important in terms of aviation but that importance is slipping, and we now see growth in the Middle East, Asia and the Pacific area. So we need to facilitate our European airlines and the aviation sector to tap into the growth potential of the fast-growing external markets. We know well the benefits of external aviation agreements. I mean, look at Morocco, at the way activity has doubled, the Balkan states, doubled, similarly with Canada and the US.  So the aviation air agreements, we have seen, are urgent, are important. We also need to look at ourselves and recognise that there are difficulties. Congestion is going to be a difficulty. We know that by 2035 two million flights will be lost due to airport capacity shortage in our airports. That will cost money and that will cost jobs. We also have the challenges of environmental targets and, of course, the files that are still sitting have not been resolved: single European sky, slot regulation, passenger rights. Commissioner, this is a time when European aviation is a success, it has been a success and it can be a success again if we equip our aviation sector to deal with the challenges that it faces today.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Telička, for the openness and patience he has had in negotiating a report that he envisaged as a strategy for the future, that is, something very concrete and essentially based on airspace. superior as a forward-looking element, but on the other hand, we also needed - as he said - to look back and take a holistic approach, precisely at a key moment of change in the aviation sector. And, therefore, turning our eyes from heaven to earth also means taking into account that the exponential growth that the democratization of travel has brought with this market opening has also brought about some problems; for example, airport capacity problems. And, in that sense, I believe that some of the proposals that appear and that we have tried to propose are fine to facilitate, through the improvement of airport capacity, territorial cohesion and the enhancement of regional airports, perhaps the idea of ​​going into the future. Clusters that had the rail links that we are trying to give them through the trans-European networks could be a formula to improve our capacity. Sensitivity in relation to the social part is also important - and I thank you for it. I believe that there we also had the need to balance, because success for travelers must be balanced with improvements and decent jobs for workers; because if they don't earn, they don't travel, and we need them to have better and more decent salaries so that they are also capable of traveling and, therefore, not subtract companies from their social obligations and responsibilities with the superior airspace. As far as technique and technology are concerned, I believe that there we have the approach, the need for better financing. Therefore, in the new MFP we will have to provide a lot of attention to the 'Connecting Europe' Mechanism, to improving financing and also to the EFSI.Regarding international standards, I thank you for your struggle and your energy, Commissioner, before the ICAO, and we should also do it before the ILO, to achieve social, environmental and technical quality standards at European level and impose them on the rest of theregions globally.And, finally, break a spear, emphasize the possibility of an idea that I leave here on the table, which is to go towards a regulated recycling of airplanes within the framework of the new circular economy that the European Union is launching.as a key idea.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to pay huge thanks to Pavel Telička. It has been excellent to work so closely with him again on this fantastic new aviation report, 99% of which is excellent in my opinion and has my full support. However, a serious problem arose because the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs was granted exclusive competence on the Social Agenda under Rule 54. Unbelievably their text infers that professional pilots on European airlines are employed on illegal, bogus contracts, thereby putting passengers in danger. None of their references are evidence-based and, in addition, comments regarding business models, such as ‘home base’ criteria, also have no place in this report, showing breathtaking ignorance, as 70% of flights across Europe come under general aviation.  Aviation is the most highly regulated form of transport. It is held to the most stringent legal safety standards with contracts of both pilots and crew having to be compliant with EASA EU OPS and flight time limitations. Therefore, these accusations are misleading, provocative and have no foundation. To make matters worse, we have been unable to amend the contribution by the Employment Committee. We have already made numerous references to good working conditions, high-skill jobs and training throughout the report, not least because all of us here support good jobs and good contracts of employment.  To conclude, this sends out the wrong signals for this committee. To suggest it is not safe for European citizens to fly on European carriers is quite disgraceful. Why should they book flights? Therefore, I am not prepared to appease this ill-thought through element of the report which has been included and which we have been unable to change, but I thank [Mr Telička ] again for the hard work, and I know he understands this position. I hope this message has got through, Commissioner, namely that we have to be very careful when we allow other committees to have so much input on certain dossiers. This was incorrect; an opinion would have been quite sufficient. Thank you. This is the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and our focus is on transport.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mister President! Yes, the Commission had already made a very good proposal for the aviation strategy in Europe. Now there is a very good report from Pavel Telička, whom I would also like to thank very much. It really is like this: We have more and more people in the world and the air is getting fuller and fuller - not only with passengers, but also with freight that has to be transported. I think it's a good idea that Pavel Telička said: We need some kind of motorway in the air. We already have that: we have motorways, we have motorways of the sea, now we also need motorways - although of course there are no cars - in the air. So we really have to think about how to make space for everyone there. Then we have to capture everything that flies. It's not just about the big passenger planes, it's also about small private planes, it's about drones, there are many things that have to be regulated, and all of that is recorded and named here. We need fair competition, not just between airports. International: Frankfurt, for example - I'm German now - has already lost its importance as a transfer airport and has been overtaken by Istanbul. It is also the case that there is a lot of competition, especially with the airlines, where you ask yourself: Is everything still fair? Do we need new rules of the game? Of course we need innovation. We have to become more environmentally friendly in air transport. I'm already waiting for the first airplane to run on algae fuel - that would be really awesome. There is also a circular economy in aircraft construction. I've already made sure of that. Lastly: Of course we have to have fair working conditions, because that also means sensible security. We need more passenger rights and we need a single European sky. I make a conscious decision to do so. This legislation has been since blocked for two years.It's actually crazy that we fly zigzags instead of clear lines.That would be much more efficient and much better for the environment.That is why we all have to fight for it to finally come.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, let me thank the rapporteur not only for his report, but also for stepping down from his original intention and focusing more on social issues in his report. Although this was done under pressure from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I am still glad that my colleague now sees a link between good working conditions and the quality of services. So I cannot agree with what my colleague Foster said, and I think it is good that other committees have also commented on this report. I am also pleased that the report calls on EASA and the Member States to continue to examine new business and employment models in order to ensure aviation safety. I believe that special attention should be paid, for example, to zero-hour contracts, which I consider to be extremely unfair to employees. I am in favor of strong European aviation, but this must not be created on the shoulders of destroyed workers, on whom the quality of services stands and falls. We need to be able to put it together, and I think my colleague has succeeded, and I would like to thank him very much for that.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! Air traffic is increasing sharply today. Admittedly, it is positive with increased mobility, but at the same time we must realize that emissions from aviation are escalating climate change. We need a policy that increases mobility but at the same time reduces emissions. For us Greens, it is of the utmost importance that aviation - just like all other modes of transport - pays for its climate costs and reduces its environmental impact. Neither current emissions trading, technology development nor other investments, such as green approaches, are sufficient to achieve this. We want to create fair rules of the game that improve the competitiveness of environmentally friendly alternatives such as the expansion of high-speed lines, comfortable night trains or even support for the development of more sustainable fuels for aviation. It is unreasonable that aviation should not bear its own costs, that they should avoid paying taxes and VAT and that so many airports are subsidized with tax money. Finally: Yesterday we voted on the reform of the EU emissions trading scheme. It was also intended to put a clear price on the climate impact of aviation. Unfortunately, yesterday's vote was another toothless reform that will not bring us closer to fulfilling the Paris Agreement. Therefore, individual member states must be able to take the lead and show green leadership and put a fair price on the climate impact of aviation. That is why we are voting in favor of this aviation strategy, which unilaterally prioritises short-term growth and competitiveness and which refuses to take responsibility for the climate.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. - I think the report is quite positive. I understand that the key aspects of the European Union's aviation strategy are competition, security and the single European sky. That's important. I understand that the proposals made by the rapporteur, Pavel Telička, from the development of the aviation model to the improvement of safety, are necessary. I also believe that the European Union's policy in the field of air transport should change from strict regulation in the field of internal competition and the position of punishers to the pursuit of a dominant position in the global air transport market, in its role as coordinator of enlargement. Small airports should be a priority for the European Union, and I therefore call on the Commission to pay special attention to them and to provide the Member States with more effective financial instruments and instruments to help keep small regional airports, especially on the periphery. But as a man with an aviation pilot’s license for more than 40 years, p. P. Telička, when I do not understand something. As my fellow aviators do not understand, at least I did not find this in the report. I do not understand why, when we are constantly talking about youth employment, we are not talking about attention, support for sports aviation, sports airports. I don’t understand why the demands on aviation organizations, especially those many of which are public, are growing uncontrollably, simply unstoppably. Why are the demands on private users, four-, two-seater planes, growing so fast that they will soon be the same as Boeing’s? I don’t understand the engineers-designers who build new, fast, safe planes and fight for every kilometer of speed, and when we arrive at the airport, we spend hours upon hours waiting for checks in the aisles. I don’t understand many airplane delays. I think that in the modern age of technology, this is not just due to meteorological conditions. I also do not understand how the rights of citizens are protected when they get on the air port, they find an airline striking.I missed that in strategy, p.P. Telička.Apparently, the old pilots' saying "Where aviation starts, order ends there" will be usable for a long time to come.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. Chairman, I have worked for more than thirty years at Air France and I have unfortunately seen the damaging effects of fierce competition in the aviation industry. By dint of wanting too much and too often deregulating for reasons of profitability, the European Union has created a framework which, ultimately, benefits much more to foreign companies and low-cost than to our historical national companies, which pay today this excessive hunting for savings. The observation is clear, whether for the large incumbent operators or the main airports, large-scale developments are taking place outside the European Union. Only the aviation industry seems to be doing well, but at what cost? Despite its commercial successes, for example, the Airbus group has resorted to relocations, reduced its budgets devoted to research and development, and reduced its workforce. Also, I vigorously dispute the expression "inadmissible tendency to protectionism", which the rapporteur has inserted in his text, because I believe that it is the reverse logic which is inadmissible, that which nevertheless presides in the institutions of the 'European Union for forty years and which has established free trade as a dogma in the name of a sacrosanct free and undistorted competition, which we can clearly see that it is a lure, including in the air sector facing these years, to unfair competition from Gulf companies. Finally, I am not too surprised, Mr Rapporteur, that you share the mercantilist vision of the Commission, since you yourself have been a member of this institution, but I consider, for my part, that it is perfectly appropriate that the public authorities defend the employment of their nationals and protect their companies. If some believe that advocating a protective framework for our airline industry is populist, then I readily accept it as a compliment. Indeed, I cannot bring myself to see several airlines disappear or fall into the hands of foreign companies, because states are not allowed to save them. Nor do I resign myself to the emergence of these new business models of pay-to-fly, letterbox companies, zero-hour contracts and bogus self-employment. On this last point, on the other hand, I can only welcome the recommendations made by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, but I nevertheless remain cautious about the will of the Commission to apply them, because in general, the latter is reluctant to sanction this type of behavior, which nevertheless harms the safety of flight crews and passengers. Proof of this is that no low-cost company is among the top ten airlines in the Jacdec ranking. That is why, unless the rapporteur responds convincingly, I will abstain from this report.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr. President, we are also experiencing in Greece the Single European Sky, the European Union aviation strategy for the privatization of infrastructure, services and airspace, with the handover - by the SYRIZA-ANEL government that follows in the footsteps of the previous - fourteen airports in the consortium Fraport-Kopelouzou. Civil aviation workers, all airport workers, are literally up in the air, not knowing if they will have a job and rights. Flight safety is compromised by cost-benefit logic. The tourism served by the airports is delivered to interconnected transport and tourist groups. Government services, such as the Fire Department, are put at the service of the individual. The control of the national airspace is handed over to private monopolies and the dangers that threaten the vital sovereign rights of Greece multiply in a region like the Aegean and in a period of time that are directly challenged by the Turkish leadership, with daily questioning of borders, air and maritime, but also the Treaty of Lausanne which defines them. People to stop the delivery of airports! A single public body of aviation for the needs of the people and not monopoly profits!

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - First of all, my thanks also to the rapporteur for this report. I think it gives a very good idea of ​​what we in Europe want from the aviation sector right now. The aviation sector is a very challenging sector, but it is also an emancipation sector. There are many European citizens who can now fly to holiday addresses and you can say a lot about that, but it is emancipation. I would like to highlight four topics this morning, firstly the innovative strength of the sector. The Committee on Transport will visit Toulouse and the Airbus factories next week to see the state of innovation in Europe. The second point is competition. Indeed, we have stiff competition in the sector, not always fair and secure from outside the EU. Then the social aspect. I have been rather disturbed by the behavior of the Employment Committee. If you have co-decision rights on a TRAN INI report, then you are definitely not going to write a message that is twice as long as the main message. In this sector we should not freeze everything and especially the young pilots deserve more attention.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, aviation is a key element of the air transport system, which is indispensable in order to ensure connectivity inside and outside the Union. As part of a strategic planning of the European airport system, I believe it is essential to enhance both international hubs and regional airports. The latter contribute to the creation of employment and the development of tourism and favor the regulation of traffic in the main European airports, promoting the integration and growth of remote areas. I therefore welcomed the communication from the European Commission on the notion of aid, as it emphasizes that public support for small airports, which mainly serve local users, is not capable of affecting trade between Member States. For these reasons, I believe it is important to support, also through State aid, investment and operation in small airports with low commercial traffic, which therefore cannot enter into situations of competition with other hubs.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - Initially, in his report, Mr Telička paid a lot of attention to innovation, competitiveness and collectivity. These are very important subjects in themselves, but aviation does have bigger problems. In a hard fight for the lowest price, various low-cost fighters pinch their pilots. This goes so far that pilots have to pay to continue flying. That is a construction known as pay to fly. That this is a major problem for both pilots and consumers was shown by a study by the London School of Economics last year. In it, many pilots indicated that they are dealing with fatigue complaints and those fatigue complaints are actually not taken seriously by these types of airlines. I am very concerned about that situation. Pay to fly is an absurd construction and actually stands for an organizational culture with great risks. I therefore understand very well that various pilot organizations are starting, or have already started, to challenge this legally and to bring down these constructions. They are also right to do so. Fortunately, the rapporteur has eventually incorporated these points into his report and I welcome that. Because of that change, because of that adjustment, I can now also support the report.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, dear fellow passengers, I would like to take this opportunity to ask Commissioner Bulcil about the use of biofuels and, in particular, about the use of second-generation waste, especially waste and residue-based biofuels.In order to reduce emissions from aviation, there is regular feedback that biofuels are preferable, but the price is often three times more expensive than a traditional fossil benchmark.If we want, and hopefully still want, to achieve the goals set out in the Paris Climate Agreement, all measures - in air transport, shipping and other transport - must be taken.I would therefore like the Commission to take steps forward so that this fossil fuel dependence can be reduced to other fuels.

name: Karima DELLI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you to our rapporteur, Mr Telička. The aviation sector is a dynamic sector in full growth: + 5% per year. In terms of CO2 emissions, this will translate into seven-fold levels by 2050, because this sector alone already accounts for 3% of global CO2 emissions. As a result, the aviation sector alone is jeopardizing the objectives of COP21. In my opinion, there is no room for such a development without a technological shift and without a strong constraint, in particular on the carbon emitted. Besides the climate, the other problem is that this sector is deregulated. Competition is unfair with airport hubs and Gulf companies; intermodal competition is unfair, for example with rail, because kerosene is not taxed. We discussed social problems, with increasingly precarious salaried employment - this is the case with pay-to-fly, "zero-hour" crew contracts - when the link is obvious between social conditions and safety. Therefore, today, it is a sector that must take into account, in an important way, the environmental aspect, the social aspect, but also the technological aspect.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, aviation and the aeronautics sector, which directly employ hundreds of thousands of people in Europe, including nearly 190,000 in France, are real pillars of growth for Europe. The European Commission understood this clearly when it presented its Communication on an Aviation Strategy for Europe in December 2015. Today we are debating a comprehensive report that takes into account the issues essential to making this sector a tool for strengthening Europe, both on its internal market and on the international stage. Aviation safety, with the reform of EASA, single European sky, air passenger rights, the global agreement on emissions caps and, finally, the international dimension of the aviation strategy are priority axes which should guide the action of the Commission and Member States beyond the aviation strategy itself. I want to emphasize one point: as in sport, I fight so that the rules of the game are the same for everyone. However, there is still so much to do in the fight against unfair commercial practices! We must realize the need to defend our European airlines and our airports. Therefore, Commissioner, I ask you to complete the reform of the regulation on unfair practices as well as on negotiations with third countries. It is by finding new sources of growth and combating unfair commercial practices that the European aviation sector will regain solid future prospects.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, the continuing success of our aviation sector is very important for Europeans, as travellers and also as workers. I very much welcome the excellent work done by many MEP colleagues in producing our views on an overarching aviation strategy. This work has included engaging constructively with the Commission’s focus on a forward-looking framework for regulation of the sector on the basis of a common European vision. Making the Single European Sky a reality, regardless of national demarcations, would benefit all of us. I, and many others, will be doing everything we can to ensure that the UK plays a full part in this project in the years to come.  On the details of this report, I believe that we as MEPs have a duty to promote the reduction and minimisation of environmental damage done by aviation and to encourage a shift to other, more sustainable forms of transport where appropriate. It is fair to say the report could possibly have done more in this respect, but I still think we should support it. However, it is extremely welcome that we are voting today in support of calls to protect the rights of workers throughout the sector. In contrast to what some others have said, most reasonable people in this Parliament agree there is ample evidence of the problems of precarious employment in the sector for pilots, cabin crew and ground staff and we must address this together.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! The aviation industry plays a very important role in generating economic growth, jobs and in creating innovation. The concern for this sector is therefore fully justified. European airlines, including Polish Airlines, generate profits and are doing very well on the global market. They should be assisted in their development in every possible way, including by negotiating favorable bilateral agreements. I am pleased that Mr Telička has paid due attention in this report to the issue of air transport accessibility, which varies greatly between regions and between Member States. With the current level of mobility, having affordable connections and airports relatively close to home is extremely important. This availability can be ensured through free competition in the aviation market, including involving non-Union players and low-cost airlines, and an appropriate level of infrastructure investment. Of course, all initiatives for the future of air transport must make passenger safety a priority. However, one cannot agree to the reckless use of this argument in all disputes, including disputes between employers and employees.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have taken the floor to ask you to vote in favor of Amendment No 2 after paragraph 15, which refers to the cancellation of the concession of 14 profitable regional airports in Greece to Fraport. This is a typical case of a colonial contract. It is the result of political blackmail as it was set as a prerequisite for the signing of the third memorandum. It violates European Union rules on state aid and competition. The technical advisor of the concession process was Lufthansa, a shareholder in Fraport. Fraport itself is largely owned by the German state of Hesse, with the result that this agreement constitutes a transfer of public property from one Member State to another. Overall, the terms of the contract exempt the company from a series of commitments and obligations of a financial nature to the Greek state, employees and local municipal authorities. Dear colleagues, if we want the Greek people to stand on their own two feet, we will not do so by taking away their public property. That is why I call on you again to vote in favor of this amendment which calls for the annulment of this colonial type of convention that has been launched.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to say to the Commission that they always claim to take an integral approach to all kinds of challenge and, indeed, we have had a couple of nice strategic reports from DG MOVE on the future of transport. But when we go into very sectoral approaches suddenly this integral approach is lost. The strategy on aviation is really a very one-sided approach, looking only at the problems of unfair competition internationally and, of course, some issues we have in the European airspace. The rapporteur, unfortunately, did not take the integral approach that is needed for the aviation sector. I am happy that, in relation to the social pillar, the report has been corrected and improved. However, on the environmental side it hardly does anything: it does not even mention the Paris Agreement. When everyone is shouting about how important that is and yet it is not even mentioned in discussion of this sector it shows that the integral approach is still lacking. When we take sectoral approaches, let us ensure that we know it is about economic, social and environmental policies. This report does not do enough in that regard, so I will vote against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, aviation is, like so many others, a sector affected by the liberalization imposed by the Commission and the privatizations of the Member States. Spain is a clear example. The privatization of AENA will manage the air infrastructures thinking about obtaining benefits at the cost of the quality of services for passengers and workers. With liberalizations and privatizations there has been a clear deterioration in working conditions in the sector. While air services have grown 47% in recent decades, employment is not growing, and temporary and precarious contracts, including zero hours, have become the norm. Collective bargaining must be strengthened and the demands of the unions must be listened to to prevent changes in airport concessions or company operating bases resulting, as now, in a worsening of working conditions. Let's avoid social dumping and, of course, let's not advance in privatization.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, (inaudible) with airlines and aeroplanes, and we are very grateful to all the carriers who take us around Europe every week. Especially coming from the island of Ireland, I must pay tribute to both Ryanair and Aer Lingus for their courtesy and efficiency at all times. Also, coming from the island of Ireland means I am very conscious of the Brexit negotiations coming up and of the effect that a hard Brexit, with Britain outside of the single market and possibly the customs union, is going to have, especially in the haulage sector. I can see, because of the major difficulties in transporting goods across Britain and on to the European Union, a huge demand for both maritime and air transport in relation to cargo, and this is going to increase the pressure. I agree with my colleague Mr Eickhout, and others, that the Paris Agreement has to be taken into consideration. We have to look at ways of reducing emissions, while maybe meeting increased demand, and that is a big challenge for us.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs and all their colleagues who have contributed to this report. As a member of the TRAN Commission, I understand the importance of the aviation sector in the context of the strategy of connectivity, competitiveness, but also of tourism development. I believe that the Council also needs to show political will in support of the development of aviation potential. Commissioner, I am convinced that you know very well that the development of aviation influences competitiveness, mobility, but also economic development in the single market. The Commission itself has estimated that there are losses of around € 5 billion a year due to delays in the "single European sky". At the same time, there are still issues related to the quality and safety of passengers and I believe that concrete measures need to be taken into account in order to protect passengers, but also to improve the quality of services. I welcome the Commission Communication entitled 'An Aviation Strategy for Europe' and the attempts to remove barriers, but I want it to be put into practice. I will vote on this report and I hope that the proposals you are receiving today, Commissioner, will be turned into concrete measures.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the new aviation strategy must aim to strengthen industry and tourism. This means, mainly, measures against monopoly situations, such as the case of Fraport, which was granted, instead of a lentil plate, 14 regional airports in Greece and even granted a "dowry", since NSRF projects are being carried out at Thessaloniki, Chania and Skopelos airports EUR 520 million, which is prohibited by European Union regulations. It is noted that Fraport operates Frankfurt Airport and airports in the Balkans. Given that Fraport's shareholder is Lufthansa, it is becoming clear that Fraport now has a monopoly position in the Greek market, turning Greece into a German tourist protectorate. This is a colonial-type concession of Greek public property to a German state-owned enterprise, in the context of the memorandum checks. This is a concession that dissolves the labor relations and puts state services in the service of Fraport, as is the case with the Fire Brigade and EKAB. I support the amendment to abolish the concession of the 14 regional airports to Fraport.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, this is a strategy that we do not see and that we condemn. We denounce its true objectives, to promote a pan-European aviation oligopoly that will result in a greater loss of national sovereignty in a highly strategic and important sector for the development of Member States, but also the intensification of the exploitation of workers, with the expected labor deregulation. , increased insecurity and reduced wages. This is a strategy born within the large multinationals of the sector, created by them and for them, to favor the European agreements with emerging markets or the recommendations for the revision of a set of regulations and directives or the increase of public investment in a logic of nationalizing costs and privatize profits serve the interests of these multinationals exclusively. Finally, the report is forced to acknowledge the brutal impact that the liberalization process has had on industrial relations, but is unable to propose any measure to reverse this direction; on the contrary, the answer is only to further deepen the sector's liberalization.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, air transport is the cornerstone of European mobility and the main way of making the freedom of movement guaranteed by the Treaties concrete. The new strategy for European aviation must first of all aim at maintaining high quality and safety standards for passenger transport, on the ground and in the air, including through incentives for innovation and targeted investments in digital technologies. Airspace is part of the single market of the European Union and its inefficient or irrational use, such as that caused by divergent national practices for operating procedures, taxes and levies, causes concrete inconvenience for citizens, an increase in costs and flight times , as well as higher fuel consumption and higher CO2 emissions. Ultimately, the aviation sector needs a work of rationalization and renewal. This must start from the European institutions, so that harmonious results are obtained and safety and accessibility of transport are kept as priority objectives.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there are many issues and many questions but first let me say thank you very much again to both rapporteurs, Mr Telička and Mr Christensen, for a very comprehensive report and a very fruitful discussion. I would like to respond to all of you, but the time is really limited, so I will try to focus only on a couple of issues. I hope we can have a further discussion through the bilateral meetings on all the topics you raised. First, just very quickly, on biofuels: in our low emission and mobility strategy we were very clear about the importance of alternative energies for transport. I have to say that, for aviation, biofuels are currently the only alternative which we will fully support.  On the topic of multimodality, which rolls with the same topic, and air quality, multimodality is certainly a very positive environmental impact, notably regarding local air quality, so we designed the TEN-T corridors fully multimodal. It has been estimated that many of the indirect CO2 emissions at airports originate from surface access transport. Developing important public transport systems is therefore key, both for environmental reasons and for fairer competition between airport modes, and we are pursuing this goal. On regional airports: these deliver very positive economic and other benefits for the communities they serve. In recent years, regional airports have begun to pursue commercial objectives and are competing with each other to attract air traffic. In this new competitive environment, public funding of regional airports may distort competition between regional airports, so allow me at this point to also mention state-aid rules, which are necessary to ensure a level playing field between regional airports. Our guidance makes clear under which conditions public funding can be justified.  Regarding the pre-check and pre-clearance programmes, the Commission is aware that at least one important international partner has commenced and implemented an expedited screening programme, so-called PreCheck, for so-called ‘trusted travellers’. As a prerequisite, such travellers need to enrol and a programme determines the level of risk posed by the individual. This issue is therefore worth exploring further.  Pre-clearance: the Commission has noted the US Preclearance programme which aims at facilitating and rendering more expeditious the process of their arrival in the US. A number of major airports in the Union and their respective state’s authorities has been approached and consulted, in order to have such an arrangement in place. This needs a series of procedural and infrastructural modifications to the current configuration in place at Union airports. EU funding on preclearance will be considered further. Regarding pay-to-fly: new employment models have emerged, such as pay-to-fly for flight crew. There is no evidence that safety is negatively impacted but the Commission and the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) are continuing to monitor the pay-to-fly scheme. I have already used up my time, so I am happy to discuss all other questions at the bilateral meetings. Thank you very much for your attention and I am really happy that we are on board together to make sure that aviation remains one of the success stories of the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by first of all thanking my colleagues Ms Clune, Ms Foster and Ms Ayala Sender. I must say I have truly enjoyed working jointly with you and I appreciate your input. You have contributed immensely. Secondly, in reaction to some of the comments: Mrs Konečná said that she is happy that I backed off on the social issues. Well, I am afraid that she cannot recall the deliberations because she did not have the time to join us for one single meeting, otherwise she would know that the social aspects were present from the very beginning. The difficulty that I had was when we received an opinion from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs which was as long as the draft report itself. Then it was extremely difficult to accommodate it. I think we need to have a certain sort of discipline. So I am glad that, together with the rapporteur from the Employment Committee, we then managed to shrink it, but as I say, it has always been present.  Secondly, on the COP: you know, it depends how we write reports. We can have a report of 20-30 pages mentioning the COPs, as important as they are – COP21 certainly – all the elements, all the documents, but nobody will read it. I am rather in favour of reports that will outline exactly the tools, the instruments with which we will manage to do it. I invite you to have a look at, for example, the connectivity index. It is there; I mean this is the tool with which we can really arrive at the outcome.  I do have a dream. My dream is that I wake up one day in the morning, I decide with the family or without to fly in the evening; that I will look at the internet, I will buy an integrated ticket which will take me from my village to Prague, then to the airport, then from the airport to another airport, and then by train – integrated ticketing, integrated modes of transport; that I will get to the airport and I will be safe; that there will be pre-screening with no extra hassle, but still security will matter; I will fly on a plane, whether it is European or international, which will have low emissions, which will be quiet, a plane with a rested crew, etc.; I will arrive without any disruption of traffic.  So this says what this report is aiming at, and I believe that if we vote for it this is yet another important step in the right direction. So thank you very much indeed. I am sure that gradually, with an active Commission, with an ambitious Commissioner, we will be able to make the dream come true.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - With the policy of opening up the European civil aviation sector to competition, European airlines are subject to two competitive pressures: on the one hand, the development of the low-cost sector and, on the other hand, the exacerbated competition from airlines, in particular from Gulf countries, which would be boosted by public aid from these states (whether direct aid or particularly advantageous taxation). This situation has resulted, as in all sectors subject to strong competitive pressure due to aggressive liberalization policies, in a deterioration in the working conditions of employees of European airlines. Thus, certain abuses such as “zero hour” contracts or “independent” work are now proven in some of these companies. This report, which follows on from the aviation strategy published by the European Commission in December 2015, recommends, in particular, the rapid establishment of the "single European sky", but ignores concrete measures to redress the situation of European companies. The absurdity of anti-protectionist dogma is coming to light as our competitors make generous use of methods in the states of the Union that are subject to strict legal limitations.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the human rights and democracy situation in Nicaragua and the case of Francesca Ramirez (2017/2563 (RSP))

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Author. - Mr President, we have gathered here today to discuss the case, and I would tell the story of human rights activist and environmental activist Francisco Ramirez, who is trying to lead an organization in Nicaragua called the Council for the Protection of Land, Lakes and Sovereignty, and seeks peacefully to protest against the Nicaraguan government's megalomaniac plan to enforce and create a canal between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. This whole project is accompanied by many questions, it is connected with the non-transparency of the whole project, with the fact that the Chinese investor has obtained extraordinary authorizations from the Nicaraguan government. Importantly, it is clear that the Nicaraguan government and state authorities are bullying these activists, who are pointing out the problems and protesting against them. Today, we are adopting a resolution calling on the government not to bully human rights activists and to allow them to protest peacefully. And I think that is crucial, because even though there may be a government project, citizens have the right to protest against it and to express their views and thus exercise their freedom of expression.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: author. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! We have just talked about aviation in Europe. It is important for the citizens of our countries. Now we have started a topic that is important for the image of the European Union, because it is important that, even in times of a major institutional and economic crisis in Europe, we show that there are certain values ​​that cannot be sold. If the values ​​that are not for sale in the European Union are the defense of human rights where they are violated, I think we have had problems with Nicaragua for many years. It is good that our Parliament, above political divisions, deals with this modest woman - Franciska Ramirez - who defends the rights of the local people, because these local people are being taken away for almost nothing to build a power plant. It is good that we are speaking on this matter. In fact, we do it for ourselves, in a way, so that we can tell ourselves in the future that we have tried to defend human rights. Perhaps years later we will recognize that it was one of the most important activities in this parliament.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. - Mr. President, it is time that we talk about Nicaragua in this House. The situation of human rights and democracy has been deteriorating for years and, therefore, I welcome this first Resolution of this legislature on Nicaragua. It is not just about the interoceanic canal and the repression against protesters who exercise their right to freedom of association and expression. Francisca Ramírez is just one example of hundreds of voices opposed to the Government, who are suffering increasingly harsh repression. The Government has been systematically undermining democratic processes and the rights of its citizens to consolidate its control of the country. The most recent example of this has been in the last elections in November, which marked the end of a rigged and unfair electoral process. In response to all this, this Resolution asks the European Union to monitor the situation and, if necessary, evaluate the possible measures to be adopted with Nicaragua, a country that is a co-signatory of the Association Agreement with Central America. The Ortega government has shown us time and again its true face and intentions. We cannot act reactively and wait until more violations occur or we will wipe out another Venezuela in Central America. Therefore, I ask the senior representative to start investigating measures that can be applied to prevent this from happening.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author. - Mr President! Isidro Baldenegro López was a farmer, environmental activist and leader of the indigenous people of Tarahumara. One month ago, he was murdered in northern Mexico. One year ago, Berta Cáceres, also a leader of the indigenous people and an environmental activist in Honduras, was assassinated. I read about these cases in the newspaper Economist this week. Latin America, writes Economist, is the world's deadliest place for those fighting to save nature and the environment. In Nicaragua, we are currently taking a stand on the case of Francisca Ramírez, another brave indigenous woman who defies threats and harassment by the authorities to stop a massive canal construction that threatens indigenous peoples' agriculture. These environmental activists are risking their lives to save the planet. They need our support. This resolution also supports the negotiation process between Nicaragua and the Organization of American States, as well as a declaration of intent to be signed by both parties before the end of February. It is an important step towards greater legal certainty. Trying to save the planet should not be associated with threats, harassment and danger to life.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: author. – Mr President, Francesca Ramirez leads the Council for the Defence of the Land, the Lake and Sovereignty, a peaceful resistance movement against the interoceanic mega-dam project which is going ahead unlawfully and without prior consultation with the local community. This mega-dam project would destroy the homes and livelihoods of thousands of indigenous people and small farmers, devastate fragile ecosystems across approximately 400 000 hectares of Nicaraguan land and further increase the country’s debt. The seizure and damage of Ms Ramirez’s vehicles by the state authorities signals the Government’s determination to go ahead with this damaging mega-project and its willingness to intimidate those who oppose it.  This resolution condemns such intimidation and underlines the need to abandon the interoceanic dam project in order to prevent the irreversible damage it will cause. We are only sorry that we were not able to support the joint resolution because it was turned into a vehicle for general political criticism of the Nicaraguan Government. While we agree with many of the criticisms, we believe that this is a misuse of the human rights urgencies process of this House.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I support this resolution. I think we must do everything in our power, in the light of the Association Agreement between the EU and the countries of Central America, to hold Nicaragua accountable to the standards and respect due to the rule of law, democracy and human rights, and this is not the case at the moment. The use of State power to intimidate journalists, exclude the opposition from political life and effect full control under the judiciary system has resulted in pervasive public corruption.  The Presidential elections in 2016 have resulted in complaints about a lack of transparency, given the absence of independent observers, as well as the fact that the single party regime makes it undemocratic. And of course, the work and personal safety of human rights defenders in Nicaragua is threatened by State-related retaliation to their activism. Notably, the case of the arbitrary detainment of environmental activist Francesca Ramirez and her family. They deserve our support, and her colleagues also, and we must work as a Union to try and get Nicaragua to be fairer in their dealings with these people.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. President, at this point we talk about the situation in Nicaragua and, especially, we refer to the harassment that an environmental activist has received in the country: the case of Francisca Ramírez, who, protesting against a mega-project that is going to be produced in the country - which has not had the necessary environmental study, which has not had the necessary consultation in the country in a work of these characteristics - it has been harassed by the Government. And we must report it, obviously. And also, in the background - and this is stated in the Resolution - we are seeing how the country's institutional system has been weakening, both in terms of the rule of law and political pluralism: in the previous elections the Union Europea did not participate as an observer, it could not do so; Two elections ago it was very, very critical; and we have also seen how there were serious cases of corruption. But it must be said that we have to be proportional and we cannot use some countries as political or ideological weapons among us; and balanced, because also, for example, we are talking about another Resolution, in this case with several murders in another Central American country - several murders, I repeat, several, not like the case of the harassment of Francisca Ramírez - such as Guatemala. Put the focus at the end on the agreements, the negotiations that are taking place today with the Organization of American States, with the Government, which we hope will improve the situation in the country, and in that the European Union has to help.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although we share many passages in this resolution, we have decided not to sign it. It is true that many passages are correct, but it is also true that, in our opinion, he should have concentrated more on the case of Francesca Ramirez and on the construction of the Interoceanic Canal by the Chinese. Instead, the main issues ended up being marginalized to focus on a political issue. Once again we face yet another violence against human rights defenders and indigenous communities in Central America. The fear we have is that a case like that of Berta Cáceres in Honduras could be repeated and we should avoid and prevent such cases from happening. The project for the construction of this interoceanic canal and the economic interests of those few who will earn a large profit from this canal are involved. We should learn from mistakes we have made in the past to try to be firmer, more decisive and more direct when we make these resolutions and get to the point and not use them for political criticism, often even instrumental.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the political situation in Nicaragua is deteriorating more and more. In the country of the eternal President Daniel Ortega, there are still evident social contradictions and a growing gap between the majority of the population and the government. Nicaragua is making headlines again in the international media due to the lack of democracy, the progressive deterioration of the rule of law and the violation of human rights. The news related to the threats against Francesca Ramirez, a Nicaraguan peasant who fights against the construction of a navigable canal between the Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean, a pharaonic work that also provides for the transfer of well 10 000 farmers without adequate repayments. Francesca Ramirez fights in defense of Nicaraguan peasants and for the protection of the environment. The acts of intimidation and violence against her must be condemned with determination. The European Union and the international community must put pressure on the Nicaraguan authorities so that this courageous farmer and her family are protected.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I am in favor of the resolution, which I have signed, after all. Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega's agreement with Chinese company Hong Kong Nicaragua Canal Development to open a canal connecting the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean has led to thousands of protests. The coordinator of the National Council for the Defense of Land, Lake and National Sovereignty, Francisca Ramírez, is leading the movement of Nicaraguan citizens who oppose the creation of the canal, as its cost is estimated at $ 50 billion and its construction is expected to harm the environment but also to limit the sovereign rights of the country, while displacing 30,000 citizens, mainly poor farmers and members of indigenous peoples, whom the government did not even consult before making its decision. Francisca Ramírez has been the target of intimidation, arbitrary detention, and both she and her family have been attacked in retaliation for her activism, all by the country's government authorities. I therefore believe that the Government of Nicaragua must respect the reactions of the people of the country and stop obstructing the exercise of the right to freedom of expression.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for bringing up this case. As you know, the European Union follows very closely the situation on human rights in Nicaragua and we had been monitoring the case of Ms Ramirez. In this instance, the European Union delegation contacted her to find out her situation during the police seizure of her vehicles, which she finally recovered. International media attention probably played a role in the rapid return of her property. This is, of course, a satisfactory outcome for an unfortunate situation that could have been avoided in the first place. The EU, however, remains vigilant. The authorities of Nicaragua must ensure that all human rights defenders can express their legitimate opinions without fear of retaliation. Through continuing contacts and monitoring, the European Union draws attention, whenever it is necessary, to human rights issues and specific situations. Increased visibility, as has been the case with Ms Ramirez, may help to resolve or minimise human rights organisations’ and defenders’ difficulties. EU officials at all levels have regular contact with key local and international civil-society organisations, human rights organisations and activists. When necessary, the EU delegation and Member States have raised – and they will continue to raise – human rights issues with Government officials. The EU and the Member States have a number of programmes and projects to support Nicaraguan and other Central American civil-society organisations. Like any other civil-society organisation, Francesca Ramirez’s organisation can apply to benefit from EU development cooperation funds, and information sessions are regularly held at local level in order to explain the process to all the interested organisations. Among the human right priorities, the delegation and Member States’ embassies present in Nicaragua have decided to focus on improving the rule of law, promoting gender and LGBTI rights, as well as social, education health rights, and encouraging civil society to participate actively in the national development agenda and in the defence of fundamental rights. I would like to take this opportunity to reassert the European Union’s commitment to human rights in Nicaragua and to reiterate the EU’s pledge to contribute to human rights defenders’ security, well-being and dignity.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received six motions for resolutions to end this debate.The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 February 2016.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the executions in Kuwait and Bahrain (2017/2564 (RSP))

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: author. - Mr President, the PPE Group strongly condemns the recent executions in Bahrain and Kuwait as well as the fact that these two countries have ended the moratorium on the death penalty put in place many years ago. Even if these are serious crimes, the use of the death penalty is unacceptable. At the same time, I regret the fact that the debate in Parliament on this essential issue is not based on the defense of Union values ​​and human rights, but on solidarity with certain countries or regimes. The plural left, including the Cinque Stelle and other followers, impose on the agenda only executions in Sunni-ruled regimes. Their Shiite friends must, in a way, be protected. However, this is unacceptable! In Iran there are more executions than in any country the left forces us to talk about. I therefore call on my colleagues from other political groups not to overlook these more alarming cases and to discuss together these serious violations of fundamental principles in all regimes, Shiites and Sunnis. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Question "blue card".- Dear colleague, I have heard something that I really don't know if it is a translation error or whatever.Did you say that we support the death penalty in Shia regimes?The 5 Star Movement?If you find me a single act, in so many years of work in Parliament, in which we supported the death penalty in Shiite regimes, I really raise my hands.I hope it was just a translation error.I remind you: the 5 Star Movement is against the death penalty everywhere in the world.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: author, “blue card” response.- Mr Castaldo, you must be happy, you have the applause of Mrs Vergiat.The problem is that whenever we discuss emergencies, only the EPP Group offers to discuss the executions carried out in this great region of the world by both Shiite and Sunni regimes.We are the only ones!Whenever other political groups come up with emergencies, it is only from the Iranian perspective.They are somewhat oriented according to the wishes of Tehran and not our fundamental values.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: As President, I have to point out a problem, which has been raised by colleagues from a very wide political spectrum, and I think we need to focus on that and not turn the reasonable condemnation of Kuwait and Bahrain for the executions into a matter of partisanship.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. - Less than eight months ago, we here condemned the political arrests in Bahrain. A year ago we denounced the torture practices in the country. In vain, the human rights situation is not improving. On the contrary, the regime is tightening the screws, making the lives of human rights activists and opposition virtually impossible. Today we are here again. This time we regret 3 deaths. These are the first executions in Bahrain since 2010 following a controversial trial and we fear more to come. I would like to make the following clear to the Bahraini authorities. We always and everywhere condemn blind violence, murder and terrorism. However, regardless of the gravity of the crimes, the age of the perpetrators, the course of the judicial process, for this Parliament the right to life is a basic human right that cannot be challenged. I think of Catherine Ashton's words: “The death penalty can neither reverse the crime it seeks to punish nor mitigate a victim's loss. It should be a relic of the past. "Unfortunately, the death penalty is not a relic in Bahrain, but again a scary reality in 2017. Finally, I would like to urge all European institutions and Member States to consider the importance of fundamental human rights in their relations with Bahrain. emphasize.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, we are deeply disturbed by the executions in Bahrain and Kuwait in January. The EU is against the death penalty, no matter in which country it is performed, no matter for what crime; 160 UN member states have abolished the death penalty or do not practise it, and that list should grow. In Kuwait on 25 January 25 people were executed, 5 of them were actually foreign citizens and there are serious concerns about whether they had a fair trial under the current system in Kuwait. But in Bahrain on 15 January three people were executed by a firing squad, and we are well aware of the lack of fair trial standards as well as allegations of forced confessions under torture, which adds to the concern that we already have about the death penalty, also regarding the circumstances in these cases. The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights of the UN said it was appalled, and shares our concern about the lack of a fair trial. We ask the Kuwaiti and Bahraini authorities to become the leaders that they can be in the Middle East and adopt a moratorium on the death penalty. We particularly call on His Majesty Sheikh Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa of Bahrain to halt the executions of two prisoners on death row, Mohammed Ramadan and Hussein Moussa. We call on both the Kuwaiti and Bahraini authorities to invite the UN Special Rapporteur on torture and inhumane treatment, and to grant him full access to detention facilities to investigate the circumstances.  There is an urgent need in both these countries for upholding human rights and respecting them, including fair trial standards, and in Bahrain we see specifically that revoking citizenship puts people in a terrible situation; this is illegal and it must stop. We have also called urgently and repeatedly for the recommendations of the BiCi report to be implemented, and we repeat this call again today.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author. - Mr President! Of course, the Socialist Group also condemns these death sentences. The EU has clear guidelines. We advocate the abolition of the death penalty in line with international law and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Article 2 of the Charter states “Everyone has the right to life. No one shall be sentenced to death or executed. " It is therefore highly worrying that both Kuwait and Bahrain have now resumed the execution of citizens after a long hiatus. This is unacceptable. The right to life is fundamental. Not even the International Criminal Court, which deals with crimes against humanity and genocide, can impose this punishment on perpetrators. In the event that we now receive reports from Kuwait and Bahrain, the minimum requirements of the legal process are not met. People are sentenced to death after summary trials and after confessions under torture. The right to life is fundamental for a state to protect. Here we see the importance of Parliament taking an even clearer position and introducing even clearer proactive work to meet the objective of a universal abolition of the death penalty.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Mr. President, the executions on January 15 of Ali Al-Singace, Abbas Al-Samea and Sami Mushaima are a sad symbol. They were executed a week after their conviction, based on a confession that there is little doubt that they were extorted under torture. Ali, Abbas and Sami are the first people to be executed since 2010. The first to be executed for political reasons since 1996. This more than justifies our resolution, which is based on the UN statements. There may still be time to save Mohammed Ramadan and Hussein Moussa, sentenced to death under the same conditions.
