We can also be concerned about the resumption of executions in Kuwait, where seven people, almost all foreigners, including three women, have just been hanged after there has been no execution in this country since 2013. In in both countries, torture is unfortunately commonplace, as is the deprivation of nationality. We should also denounce the situation of the Bidounes, literally the stateless without rights particularly discriminated against, or that of migrant workers. I regret the 'double standards' practiced by certain political groups, as we have just seen in the previous debate, and Mr Preda has just given us a sad caricature. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I have a question for you, Mrs Vergiat.You talked about forced confessions and manipulated processes.Can you cite the specific sources of your claims?Can you also indicate how many executions actually took place in Bahrain?How, for example, has the Bahraini regime progressed on human rights?Is there any positive progression?

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: "blue card" response.- It's okay to ask myself a question, but it's better to listen to me before asking one.I did say that what worried us about the situation in Bahrain and which justified our resolution was the fact that there had been a moratorium and that executions had resumed.It seems clear to me.Moreover, as our resolution says - if you've read it - suspicions of torture are based on statements by NGOs, and the biggest of them.These suspicions have been echoed by the UN, and it seems to me that this is a reliable source.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: author. – Mr President, we have had good joint working across this resolution. I do regret that the ECR was not able to be part of the compromise, eventually, but we did work hard to get a decent text before the House. It is right that where Member States have allies and have interests, the European Union is a community based on values and as a collective we can exploit and voice our values and it is right that we remain vocal within that discussion. The EU, acting as a collective, can achieve more than our individual Member States – my own in particular has not entirely clean hands in this discussion – but as a collective we can be true to our values and it is right that we should speak truth to our friends. In Bahrain and Kuwait there is a sense that they are somehow singled out unfairly for criticism, on a regular basis. It is barely eight months since our last resolution on Bahrain as well, but that is because, actually, it is a compliment. There is scope for a dialogue, there is scope for a discussion with those two countries, and there is scope for progress which we can support within those countries with our expertise.  I would refer particularly to paragraph 9 of the resolution: the resolution calls on the Bahraini Government to fully implement the recommendations of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry. Progress and reform is absolutely vital and we will continue to support that progress.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ali Al-Singace, Abbas al-Samea and Sami Mushaima, on Sunday 15 January, at the crack of dawn, received four bullets in the chest, just under a week after the Court of Cassation had confirmed their death sentences for the killing of two policemen in 2014. These are the first executions since 2010 in Bahrain. They were tortured to confess. They were not even informed of the execution, as were their family members who were not even able to attend the funeral ceremonies. Exactly ten days later, seven prisoners were hanged in Kuwait, again the first executions in four years, and a fair trial is a chimera. Cruel, inhuman, incapable of deterrence, irreversible crime: this is the death penalty everywhere in the world! Two other men in Bahrain now risk being slaughtered by the system, by the state, in the coming days, if there is no real forgiveness that we invoke to put an end to this atrocious and anachronistic practice. Selective and commercial values ​​and principles belong to other political parties and groups in this House. For the 5 Star Movement, justice will never be achieved by killing a human being, neither in Bahrain, nor in Kuwait, nor anywhere in the world, including Iran.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group.- Mr President, every time a person is born, it is good news from God that we have not stopped entertaining him.And that's why I'm always sorry when someone's life is forcibly taken away.And I am even more sorry when it is taken from someone who is considered a partner of the European Union.In the case of Bahrain, we already have the third resolution on urgency, and as Cristian Preda mentioned, it is unfortunately regrettable that we are not paying attention to other countries as well.We have never discussed urgent resolutions on the cases of Iranian citizens here at European level.We pay little attention to executions in Belarus and other countries, for example.And I think that is a great challenge for us politicians to change this situation.I personally say for the PPE: it is unacceptable to take away any life.We have not given life to man, we have no right to take him.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - In this resolution, we strongly condemn the recent executions in Kuwait and Bahrain, countries where justice has no credibility. In Manama, the way the police have faced protests in recent days for the anniversary of the 2011 uprising, shows that the human rights situation has worsened, with increasing violations, including summary executions and torture. It is essential that Bahrain authorities stop the executions of Mohammed Ramadan and Hussain Ali Moosa, who have been denied a fair trial, and commit themselves immediately to abolishing the death penalty, stop the repression and restore the party's freedom of action. of the al-Wefaq opposition, to release political prisoners and human rights activists like Nabeel Rajab and to restore citizenship to Sheikh Issa Ahmad Qassim and other dissidents, who have been unlawfully and arbitrarily revoked. For Bahrain's own security and stability, it will be vital that the authorities finally engage in dialogue for reconciliation. This obviously implies the participation of representatives of the majority Shiite population.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: -  Mister President! I want to focus on the incidents in Bahrain because of the peculiarity that there a Sunni ruling house wants to exert pressure on the majority Shiite population. These three Bahraini men have been sentenced to death for an act they are very likely not to have committed. It stands to reason that this measure was intended to intimidate the majority Shiite population. The defendants were sentenced to death in February 2015 but appealed on the grounds that their confessions had been obtained under torture. The appeal was dropped shortly before the men were officially shot. When unrest broke out in Bahrain in the course of the staged Arab Spring, the Sunni ruling family took the opportunity to decimate the Shiite population. When a bomb killed three police officers three years later, Shiites were again blamed for it and three suspects were arrested within a short period of time and despite the rather thin evidence. Since the targeted destabilization of the countries in North Africa and the Middle East, religious or ethnic conflicts have been waged that could have been prevented if the EU had not also supported US foreign policy on the ground.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: –  Mr President, in Europe we are against capital punishment in principle, but let us not forget it is up to every sovereign state to decide about this. Kuwait and Bahrain decided to have a moratorium on executions for the past 6 years, and this is something encouraging. Now they have resumed executions, of ten people, on an exceptional basis. This is very much deplorable, but my problem is that this debate is somewhat out of the context of urgency because at the same time, we know that during this year in Iran ten times more people have been executed. Where are our urgent motions for resolutions [about that]? And so I am afraid that, in neglecting Iran and bashing Kuwait and Bahrain – Bahrain is very good in providing religious freedom and tolerance – we are in a way introducing double standards, so the PPE Group has decided to abstain from this vote.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I would like to express many thanks to all those who work to raise human rights issues in this House. This is not the first time that we have spoken about the situation in Bahrain, sadly, and our message must be clear. The death penalty is always wrong, and even more so when young men are tortured into confession and then executed. All of us here must be clear that Muhammad Ramadan and Hussein Moussa must not be executed, and that the death penalty must be abolished in Bahrain, as elsewhere, including Iran. Upholding human rights and democracy makes a country stronger, not weaker. If Bahrain wants to present itself as a beacon of progress in the Middle East, then its Government must conduct itself accordingly. Instead of putting Nabeel Rajab through yet another hearing on 21 February, release him and all other political prisoners. All EU Member States, and especially the UK, must put human rights first and insist that these rights are upheld, instead of trading in arms.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the executions of three men, of Shia confession, were the first carried out in Bahrain since July 2010. In Kuwait, where, at this very moment, 50 people are on death row , the execution of seven prisoners constituted the first death sentences since 2013 and this penalty continues to apply even in the event of non-violent offenses, including drug trafficking, in flagrant violation of international law. These cruel and inhuman condemnations represent a serious setback in terms of human rights and, unfortunately, reflect a trend of increasing use of the death penalty and the lifting of moratoriums in the Arabian Gulf, endangering the region's already fragile stability. Dear Colleagues, my country, Portugal, was one of the first nations in the world to abolish the abject practice of the death penalty, a decision that I am very proud of and, at the time, Vítor Hugo himself said that Portugal was setting an example for Europe. I hope that today, Europe, especially this Parliament in the middle of the 21st century, will also be an example for the rest of the world, strongly condemning these penalties, calling for the commutation of the sentences of the remaining convicts, and reiterating its commitment to the universal abolition of the death penalty. death worldwide, including Iran.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must reaffirm its leading role in the fight for the abolition of the death penalty and for a moratorium on executions around the world. Unfortunately, in recent years we have seen a resurgence of executions in many countries, even where a moratorium was in force. In the Middle East we are witnessing a real wave of executions. In Kuwait, after a four-year moratorium, 7 of the 57 inmates who are currently on death row were hanged. In early January, Bahrain ended a six-year moratorium, carrying out the sentences of three people, all linked to political opposition circles. We must accept the appeal of the Holy Father and abolish the death penalty, whether legal or illegal and in all its forms. Much remains to be done. Slavery was abolished. The death penalty must be abolished everywhere, the world must be freed from this cruel and inhuman punishment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the situation of human rights and the rule of law in Bahrain and Kuwait is particularly worrying. Both countries lifted the moratorium on executions in January. Bahrain authorities, for the first time since 2008, executed three Shiite Muslims. In the information that comes to light, there is also talk of torture, in order for the Bahraini authorities to extract confessions. Seven people were executed in Kuwait on January 25. These are the first executions in the Emirate since 2013. These facts show that civilian executions are on the rise throughout the Middle East. Death sentences, torture and all forms of cruel and inhuman, degrading treatment or punishment are prohibited by international and European treaties and are prohibited throughout the world, whether in Shiite or Sunni Muslim states. The European Union must send a message: human rights abuses cannot be tolerated.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities of Bahrain and Kuwait have resurrected the death penalty, opening 2017 with 3 and 7 executions respectively. Moreover, in these cases there have not only been executions, which in themselves represent one of the most barbaric practices in existence, but several other violations have also been found. The trials were summary, the defendants accused the police of torture and ill-treatment. Furthermore, the return to the death penalty has sparked popular discontent, creating instability in countries. Now I want to say one thing. Listening to the interventions of colleagues Preda, of colleague Kram, it seems absurd to me that, speaking of human rights, we are still discussing justifications, you put Iran on it, you don't put Iran on it. But it is logical that the same kind of practices, the same violations apply equally everywhere in the world. It is you who continue to carry on the logic of two weights and two measures, that if a friendly state does it is a caress, if a hostile state does it it is a very serious violation of human rights. In this obsession that you have in trying to include Iran in something that has nothing to do with it - the other violations in Iran too, it is obvious that they are violations that must be condemned in the same way - you are confirmed by the followers of Trump, whom you criticize a lot. You have the same obsession.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for raising these cases of recent executions in Bahrain and in Kuwait. As you know, and all of you said, the European Union has a strong principled position on the death penalty and it is always worth reaffirming this, in particular in cases where countries have not implemented the death penalty for some time, thus giving rise to the hope that a de facto moratorium will be applied. On 15 January 2017, the Bahraini authorities carried out the execution of three people who were convicted of a bomb attack against the police which killed three policemen, including an Emirati officer. As we stressed in the statement made by the spokesman for the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, this case was particularly disappointing as it represented a serious step back, given that Bahrain had suspended executions for seven years. In addition, civil-society organisations have voiced concerns about possible violation of the right to a fair trial and due process for the three convicted, and an allegation of torture during the investigations. Most of all, we are concerned that this case might result in a resumption of executions in Bahrain. We are following, in particular, the cases of Mohammed Ramadan and Hussein Moussa, which bear strong similarities with the case of those recently executed.  On 25 January 2017 the Kuwaiti authorities executed seven people – four men and three women convicted for different criminal offences. This is the first execution in Kuwait since 2013. The External Action Service also issued a public statement on this case expressing our wish to see Kuwait returning to its previous de facto moratorium. Although recognising the serious nature of the crimes involved, we thought it was useful, because it always is, to reiterate the EU’s opposition to the use of the death penalty in all circumstances, without exception. The use of the death penalty represents an unacceptable denial of human dignity and integrity and, contrary to what some people argue, experience worldwide has demonstrated that it also fails to act as a deterrent to crime. In addition, it makes any miscarriage of justice – and those can happen in any legal system – irreversible. We look forward to continuing to engage with you and we will continue to do our utmost to ensure that this issue will be raised with the relevant authorities in Bahrain and Kuwait, as in any other country which applies the death penalty – because, of course, there are still many. We are aware that the fact of the death penalty is recognised in the legal systems of these countries but we know that authorities in other countries in similar situations have developed a pragmatic approach and have started to apply a moratorium. That is what we constantly encourage countries such as Bahrain and Kuwait to do. We will continue also, through the work with like-minded partners, with civil society and in various multilateral forums, to promote a global moratorium on the death penalty. We will be looking forward to working with you on this.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received seven motions for a resolution tabled in accordance with Art.135 of the Regulations.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 February 2016.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the seven motions for resolutions on Guatemala, in particular the situation of human rights defenders (2017/2565 (RSP)).

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Author. - Mr. President, dear Commissioner: twenty years of the Guatemala Peace Accords; long way to go, but still a long way to go. As long as there is a single victim who is a human rights defender, we cannot be satisfied — quite the contrary — neither in Guatemala nor anywhere else. But with the same yardstick: we cannot look at some governments while we stop looking at others that hold political prisoners —and today my memory goes to Leopoldo López on his third anniversary in prison. The resolution that we present is, above all, balanced. We value the steps taken by the Government - which are many - and we encourage them to continue in this fight, but we also show our concern for a situation of violence that has not been eradicated. We request the involvement of the institutions, including the European Union, in all areas, and we advocate redoubling efforts against any type of violence, pressure or intimidation: zero impunity. It is a clear commitment to freedom, democracy and respect for human rights in Guatemala and anywhere in the world. Human rights are universal and have no nationality.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for human rights in Guatemala has never been exemplary, but the situation has worsened dramatically lately. In this context, the high number of attacks on human rights defenders and those who have engaged in the fight against impunity and corruption, as well as the attacks on judges and legal practitioners, are particularly worrying. Not surprisingly, these violations are often directly or indirectly attributable to the activity of unscrupulous multinationals operating in that territory. The history of Guatemala itself has taught us, since the days of the United Fruit Company and the American government, what unscrupulous investors are capable of. But the most serious thing is that these ignoble conducts continue undisturbed even in the 21st century. Parliament has already expressed itself very clearly on the responsibility of multinational companies for violations of human rights. We cannot afford to step back. This is the time to put aside hypocrisy and support above all for some powerful lobbies and try to do something concrete towards the intellectual perpetrators of these human rights violations. We can do it and if we don't, history will ask us to account for it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: author. - Mr President, there is a state of insecurity in Guatemala, as if people's lives depend on how the wind blows, in fact on how the government wants it. The justice system is corrupt, but not only that, the justice system is also intimidated and harassed by the government. Now let's imagine what a justice system looks like that is corrupt and harassed and intimidated. It's a lethal combination, there is practically no viable justice system in Guatemala. As for human rights defenders, they are also subjected to harassment and acts of violence and threats, and in the last 14 years they have been killed; 14 people, 14 human rights defenders were killed. The world is revolting and what is the Guatemalan government doing? He decided to militarize public order - so this is the typical response of a dictatorial government: we don't like justice, we don't like human rights, we don't like people who defend human rights, and then let's militarize. Of course, this provoked protests among the population, especially the indigenous population. In short, I call on the Guatemalan government to ensure that all human rights defenders will be able to do their job and conduct effective, effective investigations with results for those who have been killed.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: author. - Mr. President, Commissioner, just a year ago I traveled to Guatemala as vice president of the Subcommittee on Human Rights and there I witnessed the extreme violence and insecurity suffered by human rights defenders, journalists, judges, leaders indigenous people — doubly if they are women — but I also witnessed the admirable work that the International Commission against Impunity is doing, and also the deep sense of justice of Guatemalans. Today, in February 2017, Guatemala is in the midst of constitutional reform and has a historic opportunity to provide a legal framework and guarantee for the independence of justice, the fight against impunity, the right of indigenous peoples to prior consultation, establishment of a mechanism for the protection of human rights defenders, as the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights are fully applied. We as the European Union will be supporting and monitoring this process. Well, except the colleagues from the United Left, who claim to defend the people, but we don't know which one. Certainly not that of Guatemala.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author. - Mr President! The situation in Guatemala is very serious: over thirty murders and attempted murders of human rights activists and journalists in the last twelve months. It speaks its clear language. Defending human rights in Guatemala is life threatening. Struggling to uphold basic democratic principles of freedom of expression is done with life at stake. This particularly affects the human rights defenders who are already vulnerable: women and the indigenous people. These cases of murder and attempted murder must be given a secure trial. Parliaments and Member States must and will closely monitor developments in the country. We want to support the steps taken in the right direction and condemn all forms of legal uncertainty, impunity or corruption. In November, the situation will be evaluated in the UN's Universal Periodic Review of Guatemala. We can not wait until then. The security situation must be rectified immediately. People should not risk their lives to uphold basic universal principles of human rights.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: author. - Mr. president; Sebastián Alonso Juan, a human rights defender shot to death while participating in a demonstration against a hydroelectric megaproject in Huehuetenango; Laura Leonor Vázquez, opposition activist for the mining megaproject known as the San Rafael Mine, also shot dead. Thus, up to a macabre figure of sixteen defenders killed and more than two hundred and fifty attacks last year in Guatemala. What do all these people who suffer these attacks have in common? Well, something that this Parliament and that also Mrs. Becerra refuse to accept: they are human rights defenders, social leaders who oppose and fight against megaprojects of multinationals that condemn them to choose between emigrating or being exploited. We are talking about hydroelectric projects such as Pojón II and Renace, mining projects such as Fénix or oil projects such as that of the French company Perenco in El Petén, all of them megaprojects of European transnational companies. It should be noted that there is a responsibility of the European Union in these human rights violations related to the activities of these transnationals in those countries, thanks to the free trade agreements of the European Union.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. - Mr. President, we welcome the drafting of this Resolution. The truth is that the situation has worsened in terms of violence and impunity. In the last year, we have had many deaths and many attacks on human rights defenders, environmental activists, even people like the director of the International Commission against Impunity, who has also been the victim of attacks against him, with which I believe which is a very pertinent Resolution. I also think it is necessary to say that, beyond the declarative, we must be able to see what the European Union can do to change this climate of impunity, and there are some things that I think are important. First: support for the Attorney General's Office and all its efforts against impunity. We expect the Delegation and the institutions of the European Union to support it. Second: there is the whole mechanism put in place in application of the judgment of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights to protect defenders. That must be supported until the end, it is very important. Third: in the reform of the judicial constitutional system, we have news that the Guatemalan Parliament may dilute the reform. It is very important that this reform is approved in its entirety and, therefore, we also want to ask the European institutions and the Delegation to insist on this line.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, it has been shown that the level of economic development is directly proportional to the rule of law. Guatemala suffers from impunity for political cases for even the most serious crimes - the murder of human rights defenders - and brutal pressure on the judiciary. But the violence also affects the indigenous tribes of the country. With such a level of the rule of law, it is no wonder that the country is not doing well economically either. Perhaps Guatemala might not be the third largest recipient of EU development aid in Central America if our pressure to change conditions was a little stronger. Here, too, we can improve something. Firstly, to link more closely human rights to development aid. Secondly, to hear the part of today's resolution calling on all Member States to ratify the EU-Central America Association Agreement. It will also make it possible to formally hold a so-called political dialogue with Guatemala and thus improve the human rights situation of this beautiful country.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. president. This is a Resolution that contains three main sections, ladies and gentlemen. On the one hand, a call for solidarity with a people that suffers, a people as a whole that is suffering a horrible situation. But it is, above all, a hug to those who defend human rights and freedoms, the NGOs, the human rights defenders, who are the ones who are being victims of this horrible situation in Guatemala. And it is also a condemnation of organized crime, of narcocrime, which is to a large extent the cause of the problems suffered by the people of Guatemala. It is also a demand on the Government of Guatemala to advance in the defense of human rights and in the protection of human rights defenders. It is also a call to the Government of Guatemala to ensure the independence of the judiciary and the thorough investigation of criminals and, above all, it is a call to the Government of Guatemala to continue fighting against crime and corruption in that state. And finally, it is a call to the European Union to help Guatemala. Not to restrict aid, to help you fight what you are suffering.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the fundamental basis of a democracy is a strong and dynamic civil society. To have an active civil society, other elements also have to be present. For example, a minimum level of protection guaranteed by the State. Human rights have to be founded on the rule of law and protected by an independent judicial system. We have to say it clearly. Conditions in Guatemala are not only worrying and risky for human rights defenders but for pluralism and democracy as a whole. Guatemala has made great strides in the criminal prosecution of corruption cases and human rights violations. But despite this, there are still tragic cases of targeted killings of journalists and human rights defenders in the country. As the European Union, we must strengthen our cooperation with Guatemala to help this country promote and consolidate an agenda on human rights.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, impunity, violence and security threats have hindered progress towards more efficient law enforcement in Guatemala, whereas human rights defenders have been subjected to numerous forms of abuse and even murder, as has been outlined by some of my colleagues, one of whom actually visited Guatemala. This is not acceptable, and we have to speak out against it. Also, the participation of Guatemalans in the drug-supply and illegal-migration route between Central America and the United States is a matter of major concern, leading to all kinds of corruption, violence, murders and misery for thousands of people.  Therefore with my parliamentary colleagues, I wish to express my support for law-enforcement efforts and a strengthening of the judiciary in Guatemala. Also, as my colleague Mr Svoboda pointed out, if we are providing development aid we should just insist on certain standards. I think sometimes we are too easy and too slack in this regard and it is something that I think we really have to look at where there are continuous abuses of human rights, and indeed murder, of those who are trying to defend human rights.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I want to subscribe to this resolution, which was prepared by my colleagues. I consider it very good and right that we are talking about the protection of human rights in Guatemala. As has been said several times here, it is the country with one of the greatest internal violence, it is the country with the highest number of homicides in the world, but at the same time only four percent of these murders go to trial and the perpetrators are convicted. It has already been said here that the victims of murder are often human rights defenders, activists, journalists, and it is therefore clear that we, as a body that criticizes human rights violations anywhere in the world, must criticize the situation in Guatemala. Perhaps it is a little encouraging that the Guatemalan government wants to make changes that could make the Guatemala judiciary work better in the future. We should therefore have an active dialogue with Guatemala and push the Guatemalan Government to genuinely implement judicial reforms that will lead to future killings being investigated and perpetrators brought to justice and convicted.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe cannot remain indifferent to the episodes of violence which are affecting members of organizations in defense of human rights in Guatemala, among which 14 murders were recorded in 2016 alone. Those most affected by intimidation are activists who fight against impunity and corruption and for the protection of the environment, who have often become victims of real defamation campaigns by local businesses. Europe must support the Guatemalan authorities to take action to identify and prosecute the perpetrators of these criminal acts and to work to publicly recognize the activity of human rights activists as legitimate, countering the hateful messages addressed to them. The program for the protection of human rights defenders, enshrined in a 2014 ruling by the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, needs to be fully implemented. In this sense, Europe can and must make its voice heard, strengthening cooperation with Guatemala to support the country in the process of affirming democracy and human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, attacks on human rights defenders in Guatemala are a daily occurrence, and since 2015 there have been complaints from NGOs about nine killings of activists who opposed plans to build infrastructure or open mines. The Guatemalan government's attacks target mainly those who defend the land, especially in areas where indigenous communities reject the multinationals' plans to exploit Guatemala's wealth. In addition, the country's authorities are turning against not only the activists but also the judicial authorities who undertake to investigate the attacks against the activists. In the face of the daily human rights abuses, the European Union is called upon to condemn the freedom of speech in the country, the oppression of the local population and, at the same time, to send a message to the Guatemalan authorities that they must finally stop persecuting of human rights.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Amnesty International has denounced the plight of human rights defenders in Guatemala several times. There are many recorded episodes of killings, threats and torture, aimed above all at preventing activists from carrying out their activities. Often, in fact, they are forced to abandon their homes and their country. The main actors at risk are activists who deal with economic, social and cultural rights. The episodes of violence take place within a climate of total impunity for the perpetrators. I am confident that, also through the European Parliament, pressure can be put on the government of Guatemala to protect the safety of activists, by taking concrete measures to protect and prevent, investigate and punish abuses and threats to the detriment of human rights defenders. . The impunity of the perpetrators of these crimes must be ended in the country, which is a cause for alarm for the international community.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the execution of three men, I apologize, I was wrong, the legacy of 36 years of internal conflict and violence, the high levels of poverty, drug trafficking, the proliferation of arms, fragility of institutions and a culture of impunity make Guatemala one of the most violent countries in the world. This violence dramatically affects human rights defenders, especially environmentalists and defenders of the right to land, as statistics illustrate. In addition to other non-accountable forms of intimidation, between January and November last year, more than 200 cases of aggression and 14 murders were recorded and this year, 2017, already has the sad record of the murder of two more activists: Laura Leonor Vásquez Pineda and Sebastián Alonso Ruan. If, in 2012, the European Union's relations with Guatemala were strengthened with the conclusion of the association agreement with Central America, Europe cannot help but, from this House, now encourage the Government of President Jimmy Morales and the Guatemalan authorities to develop and implement public policies to protect human rights defenders against organized crime and send a clear and unmistakable signal of support to all those who, despite intimidation, fight courageously for independent justice and an end to impunity in Guatemala.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are indeed very concerned about the number of murders of human rights defenders in Guatemala, especially the case of Sebastian Alonso Juan, and the continuous and increasing number of killings of human rights defenders in Guatemala. The promotion of human rights is a key principle which guides our action globally and therefore we follow closely the situation in the country.  While the overall population in Guatemala is suffering from widespread violation of human rights and violence, human rights defenders continue to be particularly affected, especially indigenous leaders, journalists, trade unionists, LGBTI communities and members of the judiciary. Although in 2015 and 2016, reports of aggression incidents have fallen compared to previous years, assassinations have increased and acts of intimidation and defamation are on the rise. Fourteen activists were killed last year alone, and the year of 2017 has sadly already witnessed the murder of yet another human rights defender.  The EU has strongly condemned these hideous crimes and urged the effective prosecution of material and intellectual authors. Limited capacities and resources have hindered the provision of an adequate response by the State’s institutions, and together with a perception of corruption and impunity, provoke mistrust of the institutions. This makes EU cooperation and partnership with Guatemala to consolidate institutions even more important.  The Guatemalan authorities have taken a series of decisions that point in the right direction and therefore deserve praise and support, such as the extension of the mandate of the International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala up to 2019 and the prosecution of alleged corruption cases, including at high level. Still, more needs to be done to address the situation. This year will be of significant importance for Guatemala with the preparation of the 28th session of the Human Rights Council Universal Periodic Review. Numerous legislative initiatives are being discussed in the Congress, inter alia the constitutional reforms, that many of you referred to, in the justice sector, the policy of the protection of human rights defenders, the abolishment of the death penalty, which if properly designed and adopted and effectively implemented may constitute significant progress for human rights. Other areas for further progress include the establishment of a mechanism for free and informed prior consultations in line with ILO Convention 169, and the implementation of precautionary measures granted by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights to activists. Respect for human rights is a key commitment of the EU agenda in Guatemala. The EU is supporting and encouraging efforts on human rights challenges, including women and children’s rights, prison conditions, police behaviour, allegations of torture, corruption, collusion and impunity.  The EU has also renewed its support to the International Commission against Impunity and will further engage to support anti-corruption and prevention of violence against women and children. The EU Special Representative for Human Rights also visited Guatemala last June and had the opportunity to recall the imperious necessity to improve the situation.  And finally, I would like to take this occasion to pay tribute to all the activists that selflessly and at great risk continue to fight for human rights, good governance and the rule of law in Guatemala.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Madam Commissioner, thank you for your important speech.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- This resolution condemns in the strongest terms the recent murders committed in Guatemala in 2016. I express my concern at the serious difficulties faced by human rights defenders in carrying out their activities.It is necessary to develop a public strategy for the protection of human rights defenders, as indicated by the Inter-American Court of Human Rights in 2014. Finally, at the general level, I call on the EU institutions to conclude binding agreements at international levelaimed at strengthening respect for human rights, in particular as regards EU-based companies operating in third countries

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We also have the pleasure of having with us today in the visitors’ gallery a delegation from the Georgian Parliament, led by our colleague Ms Tamara Khulordava, within the framework of the fourth meeting of the EU-Georgia Parliamentary Association Committee, which has just taken place. I am very happy to welcome you to our plenary, especially on this occasion, and I am certain that you have had productive discussions with our Members. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: premier ministre du Canada. – Monsieur le Président Tajani, distingués parlementaires, Mesdames et Messieurs, bon avant-midi. C’est un privilège pour moi d’être ici aujourd’hui. C’est la première fois qu’un Premier ministre canadien en poste prend la parole devant le Parlement européen. Aussi, je tiens sincèrement à vous remercier de m’accorder cet honneur. Comme vous le savez, j’étais à Bruxelles, il y a quelques mois, pour signer officiellement l’accord économique et commercial global et l’accord de partenariat stratégique. Le Président Tusk, le Président Juncker, le Premier ministre Fico et moi-même avons fait un grand pas en vue d’approfondir notre relation et d’accroître les échanges commerciaux libres et progressistes entre le Canada et l’Union européenne. Et hier, nous avons franchi une étape importante.  This year we celebrate 41 years since the diplomatic mission of the European Commission was established in Ottawa, which noticeably happened under a different Prime Minister Trudeau (‘plus ça change…’), and over the course of our historic partnership Canada and the EU have stood side by side on the things that matter, things like maintaining global security, advancing the values of peace and justice, creating good jobs for our people through trade and investment. We have worked together on climate change and on the rights of women and girls around the world. And, my friends, I am confident that we will achieve tremendous things together in the years to come for the countries we represent and, most importantly, for the people we serve.  The European Union is a truly remarkable achievement and an unprecedented model for peaceful cooperation. Canada knows that an effective European voice on the global stage isn’t just preferable, it’s essential. We know that the EU is the world’s largest donor of development and humanitarian assistance and that together your Member States constitute one of the world’s largest economies. You are a vital player in addressing the challenges that we collectively face as an international community. Indeed, the whole world benefits from a strong EU.  (Applause)  Au nom des Canadiens, je tiens à vous remercier pour cette relation soutenue et respectueuse ancrée dans notre culture, notre histoire et notre amitié. En fait, les liens qui unissent le Canada et l’Union européenne sont devenus un exemple de collaboration internationale.  J’aimerais remercier Dan Costello, l’ambassadeur actuel du Canada auprès de l’Union européenne, d’avoir servi notre pays de façon exemplaire.  Je dois aussi remercier et souligner le travail extraordinaire de notre négociateur en chef pour cet accord historique, Steve Verheul, pour son service exceptionnel, son travail acharné tout au long de chacune des étapes qu’il a été nécessaire de franchir ces dernières années. Merci. Je tiens aussi à souligner la nomination de notre nouveau porte-parole senior pour le continent européen, notre nouvel ambassadeur pour l’Union européenne et pour l’Allemagne, l’honorable Stéphane Dion. Stéphane, qui est pour moi un ami proche et un mentor, est un homme qui s’est longtemps battu pour faire de notre pays un endroit meilleur pour tous les Canadiens. Il représentera fièrement le Canada, avec courage et conviction, alors que nous amorçons ensemble ce nouveau chapitre important. Maintenant, permettez-moi de souligner encore une fois à quel point je suis honoré de représenter le Canada dans ce lieu historique aujourd’hui. C’était une priorité pour moi de venir à Strasbourg et de m’adresser à vous, parce que j’accorde beaucoup de valeur à notre relation et à ce que nous partageons. I believe that the relationship between Canada and the EU is so resilient because it is centred on an important bedrock of common values, values that shape and define us, values that Canadians and Europeans share. You see, collectively, we believe in democracy, transparency and the rule of law. We believe in human rights and we believe in inclusion and in diversity. We know that, in these times, we must choose to lead the international economy, not simply be subject to its whims, and we know that the state has an important role to play, not only in supporting its people, but also in creating the conditions for progress. And to this last point, we have just demonstrated to the world that we collectively value trade and the promise of prosperity for all our citizens that comes with it.   Hier, en plus d’avoir ratifié l’accord de partenariat stratégique, ce Parlement a voté en faveur de la ratification de l’accord économique et commercial global (AECG). Après des années de négociation, cet important accord commercial s’apprête à franchir la ligne d’arrivée. Je pense que nous pouvons tous nous entendre pour dire que l’AECG était un projet extrêmement ambitieux et, donc, s’avérera aussi être l’une de nos plus grandes réalisations. J’aimerais exprimer ma sincère reconnaissance à l’ancienne ministre du Commerce international du Canada, qui est maintenant notre ministre des Affaires étrangères, Chrystia Freeland, encore une fois, à notre négociateur en chef, Steeve Verheul, ainsi qu’à leurs homologues de l’Union européenne pour les efforts inlassables qu’ils ont déployés en vue de conclure cet accord. Je suis certain que notre nouveau ministre du Commerce international, François-Philippe Champagne, sera une voix forte pour le Canada sur la scène internationale au cours des prochaines années. Je sais que je peux compter sur les nombreux talents de François-Philippe pour travailler avec la communauté d’affaires et tous les citoyens dans le but de franchir les étapes nécessaires afin que cet accord atteigne son plein potentiel. Now let’s be clear. A deal as ambitious as CETA takes a lot of hard work. Every one of us in this room knows that it wasn’t easy. It took a lot of back and forth. It took extended discussions and negotiations, meetings in Canada, meetings in Europe. We can’t overstate how important it was to get this deal right. Trade needs to work for people, for people who are struggling to make ends meet and raise their families, for people who worry that their future or their children’s future won’t hold the same promise and opportunities that it did for past generations. The people we represent will support trade if it creates better jobs and makes their lives more affordable. That’s what they expect of us, and I for one fully intend to make sure that we deliver.  (Applause) My friends, we are all seasoned politicians in this room. We know it is always much, much easier to point out problems than it is to solve them. It’s harder to work to build than it is to tear things down. Well, with CETA we have built something, something important, especially at this moment, on your continent and mine. Now we need to make it work for your people and mine. If we are successful, CETA will become the blueprint for all ambitious future trade deals. If we are not, this could well be one of the last. So make no mistake about it, this is an important moment. The motto of the European Union, ‘United in Diversity’, is a great reminder of what can be accomplished when we recognise that we are stronger, not in spite of our differences but because of them.  (Applause) Now we live in a time when many people are worried that the current system only benefits society’s luckiest few, and their concern is valid. The anxiety people have toward the economy and trade, the worry that our kids won’t have access to the same jobs and opportunities that we had, can be addressed only if we ensure the trade is inclusive so that everyone benefits. And this agreement, the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement, delivers just that, because at its heart CETA is a framework for trade that works for everyone.  Cet accord mènera à la création de bons emplois bien rémunérés pour la classe moyenne. Il permettra d’assurer le bien-être des familles et contribuera à faire croître et à renforcer nos communautés. Disons que vous êtes un jeune entrepreneur qui propose un nouveau produit ou une solution novatrice et que vous faites face au grand défi d’atteindre de nouveaux consommateurs: l’AECG vient de vous ouvrir la porte vers de nouveaux marchés. Vous êtes un consommateur qui souhaite acheter des biens importés, mais vous les trouvez trop chers? Prenons, par exemple, les magnifiques bottes d’hiver Mukluks fabriquées par Manitobah, une entreprise canadienne fondée par des autochtones, sont actuellement assujetties à une taxe européenne de 17 %. Grâce à la ratification de l’AECG, ces tarifs douaniers sont éliminés et vous, en tant que consommateur, pourrez payer moins cher lorsque vous passerez à la caisse si vous voulez de magnifiques bottes d’hiver! Trade that is free and fair means we can make the lives of our citizens more affordable and create more jobs, it means that manufacturers can expand their products’ global reach, gaining market share, and successfully compete with the best in the world. And it means that folks working in service sectors like engineering, architecture and information technology will see greater predictability and transparency when dealing with international clients. At the end of the day, both Canada and the EU want to do what is best for our people. We want  hard-working people to make a good living and support their families. We want mums and dads to be able to give their kids better opportunities than they ever had. We want each generation of Canadians and Europeans to be better off and to have a higher standard of living than the one that preceded it.  Deals like CETA, which is centred on the idea of trade that is both free and fair, will get us there at the end of the day by making it easier to buy and sell products. We can expand opportunities for our businesses, both back in Canada and right across the EU, for everyone – for small businesses, for entrepreneurs, for hard-working farmers and fishers. We can create jobs for the middle class and make sure that the benefits of trade reach our citizens. Mais, soyons clairs, il ne s’agit pas uniquement de commerce, d’importations, d’exportations ou de profits; il s’agit d’améliorer la vie des gens. L’AECG est un plan d’action complet pour assurer une coopération économique responsable entre les pays. Cet accord moderne, axé sur l’avenir, est le reflet d’un agenda commercial réellement progressiste avec des dispositions qui protègent la capacité qu’ont les sociétés à favoriser l’intérêt public.  L’AECG assure que les gouvernements peuvent continuer de protéger leurs citoyens: protéger la main-d’œuvre, promouvoir les pratiques responsables en matière d’investissement, assurer la salubrité des aliments et la sécurité des consommateurs, renforcer la gestion des forêts, des pêches et de l’aquaculture, et assurer la bonne gestion de l’environnement.  Mes amis, il s’agit véritablement de l’un des accords commerciaux les plus durables et progressistes au monde. À tous les députés présents, merci du travail acharné que vous avez accompli au cours des dernières années pour faire de cet objectif ambitieux une réalité. Je sais que tous nos citoyens s’en trouveront mieux servis.  Canada and the European Union have been friends, partners and allies for a very long time, and our natural, easy relationship is grounded in what we have in common. We share goals and aspirations for a better, safer and fairer world. We want to do what is right by the workers and families we were elected to represent. And we embrace change, seeking the opportunity to lead in a global economy that is constantly evolving. CETA and the SPA, these landmark agreements, are a direct reflection of what we have in common, and they will serve to benefit Canadians and Europeans alike for generations to come. In the things we have agreed upon so far, and in the discussions that lie ahead, the Canada-EU strategic partnership will forever be rooted in respect with an eye to the future. My friends, dear colleagues, it’s safe to say that this is just the beginning for Canada and the European Union. The best is very much yet to come.   Merci à tous.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, dear Prime Minister. Your visit to Strasbourg is only the beginning of a new season of better cooperation between the European Union, the European Parliament and your country, Canada.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes) - before the beginning of the vote:

name: Sander LOONES
text: - Today we are voting here in plenary on three reports on the future of the European Union. I will talk about the Berès / Böge report. I do not think we can vote on this report here in plenary this afternoon because the text before us is not the same as the one voted on Monday in the ECON / BUDG committee. On Monday there was no vote on compromise J of the text. I have the voting list here with me. That text was not voted on, but I do see that compromise J and thus points 2, 3 and 4 appear in the text on which we should vote in plenary this afternoon. This is not possible. This is a different text than the text in committee. Nor has the text been tabled here today, by way of amendments or anything. So this is another text. And it is also an important text, it is about content, namely about the President of Parliament who must refer to the Council, and so on. So I honestly believe that we cannot vote on this text and that federal Europe will have to wait a while.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr Loones, I take this as a motion to postpone the vote. We will come to that when we come to the report. I will get back to you with the information.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Mr President, I want to express my dismay at the way the drivers here in Strasbourg were treated. They have been working diligently for us for eight, ten, fifteen years and from one day to the next they were let go, without any letter of appreciation – nothing. I think this is a disgrace for this institution.  (Applause)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, colleague.The approval of colleagues shows that you have raised a sore point.We'll pick that up and take care of it.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- Mister President!On behalf of my group, I propose, pursuant to Rule 59 (3), that the amendments be put to the vote first and only then that the final vote be taken.There are two sufficient reasons for this.The first reason is that the amendments relate to very essential fundamental rights and to the observance of the rule of law, which we actually want to see implemented.It is also about maintaining the relationship between freedom and security in the fight against terrorism.The second reason is that trialogues are of course opaque and should at least be made clear in the amendments on the basic issues on which the dissent within the European Parliament exists.Therefore we ask for your approval.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: So: The motion is: not to vote now on the agreement of the compromise amendment 101, but first all the amendments individually before a vote can be taken.I'll put it to a vote.(The request will be denied.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr Loones, are you asking that the vote on this report be postponed?

name: Sander LOONES
text: - To be clear, this is not a postponement of the vote.This is simply not possible.The text now before us is a different text than the text that was voted in committee.And no amendment has been tabled to correct the mistake.So we cannot vote on that today.This is not a political choice.This is a technical-legal fact that must be rectified.It's not something we can fix by voting on that here.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr. Loones!The services assure me that this is a formally correct procedure, the plenary is sovereign.You can ask the plenary to postpone the vote.If you don't, we will vote on it now.So are you asking the plenary to postpone the vote on the report or shall we vote now?

name: Sander LOONES
text: Then I ask the vote on the postponement.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Is there anyone who would like to speak for this proposal?

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: – Mr President, I would like to speak in favour of the motion from Mr Loones because his argument seems only rational. We are a European Parliament so there should be proper translation in any language.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Is there anyone who would like to speak against this proposal?

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, I believe you have summed up the situation perfectly.Everyone knows the text as it was tabled.We have just voted on the Verhofstadt and Brok-Bresso reports.It is now time to vote on the Böge — Berès report.We therefore vote against this postponement.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: - Mr President, allow me to do something unusual, I rely on your understanding.My colleague Mercedes Bresso is not here, but she has collaborated in an absolutely intelligent and active way, together with colleagues Berès, Brok, Böge and Verhofstadt, to build an understanding on these relations.Europe and the European Parliament give an important answer: more growth, the ability to rethink and review the Fiscal Compact, unemployment insurance for young people, a Europe that knows how to respond to the challenges of citizens.For this I thank Mercedes Bresso and I thank all the rapporteurs and the majority who voted on these reports.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The thanks to Ms. Bresso have arrived.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I would like to say that I supported the proposal for a directive on combating terrorism. I see this as a clear answer to citizens who are worried about their security, and I think that is exactly what they expect from the European Parliament and the European Union. I welcome the unification of facts across the Member States. The directive introduces offenses of traveling abroad for the purpose of terrorism, criminal sanctioning of terrorist trainers, participation in the activities of terrorist groups, etc. The draft directive also responds adequately to the phenomenon of increasing numbers of individuals traveling abroad for terrorism, so-called foreign fighters. The directive therefore introduces a mandatory exchange of information on the movement of potential perpetrators of terrorist acts and gives more rights to victims of terrorist acts and strengthens their protection in the field of health care, legal aid. I therefore think that the draft directive is indeed a successful update of criminal law, which will lead to greater coherence of national provisions of criminal law, and thus respond to the security challenges facing the European Union.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President, while I agree with the general objective of harmonising the definition of terrorist offences at European Union level, I believe the directive contains also many flaws and challenges. Firstly, I am concerned about the definition of terrorist offences in Article 3 since they include the destruction of infrastructure likely to cause major economic loss. I am also alarmed by Article 5 on public provocation to terrorism, which criminalises the indirect provocation to commit terrorist offences. Finally, I am also critical of Article 9 on the criminalisation of travelling. I still do not see the point of criminalisation of travelling in itself, since other offences are enough to prosecute suspected foreign fighters. I think, in that case, we are going too far and we need to have more clear definitions.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, the first rule of government is to protect the people of your country, but in Brussels and Paris and in Germany, the governments of Europe and the European Union failed, as innocent people were murdered by terrorists – both home-grown and those that used Schengen and the open border system to infiltrate Europe and kill those people. You have criticised Hungary for taking its own measures. You have criticised people like myself on this side of the House, who suggested before Merkel made her monumental failure of opening the doors to Germany, that you should have checked the people coming in. You should have ensured that security was there, but no, you would rather call us xenophobes and racists, instead of listening to the sensible truth. But this report still does not go far enough. It is simply a sticking plaster, and until you put in proper border controls there will be more terrorism on this continent.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, what does the future of the European Union look like?If we design a two-speed Union, it will not look good, and this project proposes: a two-speed Union.That is why I voted against this report.Yes, the Union has been hit by crises to which it has responded difficultly and inefficiently, often too late, but the solution is not a union of euro area states and the answer is only a united union of Member States.Where did the principle of "unity in diversity" disappear?It's just a slogan, isn't it a reality for us?Yes, we need to reform ourselves, we need to reform the European institutions, there must be fewer institutions, we need to be careful how we spend money, we need to be more transparent, we need to be more modest in spending.Yes, all this is true.We must also have a single seat in the European Parliament, but, I repeat, not a two-speed union.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: - (FI) Mr President, these three reports on the functioning of the EU are based on the premise that a functioning Union means a common finance minister, a common foreign minister, top candidates, a smaller Commission, debt solidarity and a common budget for the euro area.I am in favor of European cooperation, and it must change, but the structures will not solve the current problems unless there is a common will, there is no vision, there is no direction, there are no clear plans.All these reports are missing presentations.They do not solve the problems we have.We lack jobs, we lack economic growth, inequality grows instead, there is tax evasion.These have no answers to these.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: –  Mr President, this week we had a serious debate in the European Parliament about the future of Europe. We discussed not only how to develop the European Union but also this issue: is there a future for the European Union? It is rather symbolic that this question has become topical after 60 years of existence of the common European project.  The European Union now is a big building under construction. The construction work is going very slowly. The inhabitants are not satisfied because the living conditions in an uncompleted building are not good. Some of them are trying to find a simple solution to stop the construction of the common building: they invite us to return to having separate national states. In my point of view, we cannot return to the past and national states only. We have to complete our building, and only then will we receive the full positive effect of it.  One of the main elements of this European building is common social policy. We need not only a common market, the free movement of capital and the workforce, but also the robust basis of common social standards in the EU.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: - Sir. Chairman! I voted in favor of Guy Verhofstadt's report. It was not a difficult choice because I am a declared federalist, but that was not actually why I voted for it. It is in recognition of the fact that we stand with a Europe which, in relation to solving the great challenges we face at this time, in relation to solving the security crisis of the citizens of Europe, must recognize that that our collaboration in many ways rests on a dysfunctional basis, which is due to a system failure. Therefore, there is a need for some to dare to think new thoughts, and there is a need for the Heads of Government to also recognize that there is a need for changes in the structure of our cooperation. However, I would like to make a single point when I say that I have voted in favor, and these are the elements that have to do with the political distribution policy, because they do not belong in such a report. For example, the "Financial Transaction Tax" has nothing to do with federalism. It is a question of socialism or liberalism, and all these political things must be accommodated within a federal union, and therefore it should have been taken out of the report. But nonetheless an excellent report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I did not support Mr Verhofstadt's report, I personally believe that it is necessary to talk about how to solve Europe's problems, but in my opinion, the answer to the current problems is not another accelerated integration.I believe that, if we follow the path proposed by Mr Verhofstadt's report, on the contrary, the steps contained here will lead to a rise in anti-European integration in some Member States, and it may be that the example of Brexit may follow.and other countries.That is why I voted against the report, precisely because I would not like to see the further disintegration of the European Union.I am in favor of European integration, but the proposal that has been approved today is, in my view, completely utopian, dead-end and very far removed from the real moods of the citizens of the European Union in the individual Member States.So I hope that in the end it will only end with this theoretical report.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Guy Verhofstadt's report is a denial of Europe as it is.In this sense, it contradicts the European unity it invokes.If we really want a Europe of solidarity, we should be guided by a short, simple rule: as much common competences and institutions as common values and interests.Today, unfortunately, Europe is going through a deep moral crisis and is not a community of values, but fortunately Europe remains a community of fate.We have a common history, we have common institutions and we feel the need for common interests.However, if we are to build genuine European solidarity on this basis, it is above all those who talk about it, if they really want it, to respect each other and abandon arrogance and federalist fanaticism.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: - Mr Chairman!I voted against for fundamental reasons.We are implementing a project that is inconsistent with the assumptions, and the assumptions were right.The European Union was to be a forum of understanding between independent and sovereign states to ensure the peaceful development of Europe.Meanwhile, we are implementing a completely different project.We are implementing a project that deprives the state of independence and sovereignty, that violates this sovereignty and independence, imposing some universal laws and rules.If such laws and principles were appropriate for every country, they would have existed in every country for a long time.If there are different legal solutions, because the problems of individual countries are different, then this should be respected, so the intentions of this Union should be respected and the peaceful development of independent and sovereign states in Europe should be achieved.I am in favor of such a project, which is why I voted against.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - I think that, although this resolution was approved by a narrow majority today, it is right that we also start talking about the future of the European Union in terms of redefining the institutions, because what we have today has become apparent in times of crisis, both economicas, of course, migrant and crisis values, as an organization in need of airing, needs a new freshness, and therefore I think it is appropriate to open up topics about the future role of the European Parliament, especially in relation to the Commission on the one hand and inrelation to the World.Sometimes it seems relatively unusual from the outside that, of course, the Council can have a significant influence on Parliament's decisions, and even when Parliament passes certain laws, it always, of course, needs the consent and assent of the European Council.And here a particular question arises about the role of national parliaments, and this needs to be discussed.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: - Mr President, this report, like the other two, suffers from the same problem: it claims to recognize the freedom of peoples, provided that the freedom of money is protected. This is the doctrine of ordoliberalism. I prefer to tell you that, even if you constantly put forward the need for a Europe of war, renamed "Europe of defense", to unite the peoples of Europe, you will not achieve anything as long as you want. no social harmonization, as long as you don't want fiscal harmonization, as long as you don't want independence from NATO. You leave only one perspective to the peoples who want peace, social progress and independence: whether they come to say to themselves "this Europe, either we change it, or we leave it. ". What has started is not the expected positive change, it is that people are starting to leave Europe. It is pitiful that your response to Brexit is only the Europe of defense and the constitutionalization of financial rights.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, one would indeed almost succumb to despair when one sees the same people over and over again, providing the same bad answers to the key questions of European integration. Mr Verhofstadt, the author of this report, is one of them. He still dreams of a centralized "euro state", he dreams of all power being transferred to Brussels, to institutions such as the European Parliament, the European Commission. Unfortunately, the majority of the European Parliament, although fortunately it is already a weak majority, still hears about it. And that is exactly the path in the opposite direction than we should go. We do not need a centralized superstate, we need a flexible, decentralized, multi-speed Europe, and I would not really be afraid of that Europe more quickly, because that is the only thing that can get the architecture of the European Union out of the impasse. I would recommend that Czech voters read the report and, above all, read which of the Czech MEPs voted for it. So it was definitely not me.

name: Alex MAYER
text: –  Mr President, ahead of this vote I thought I should do some research. So a couple of weeks ago I met a robot. As science fiction hasn’t yet become science fact, I also met experts from the world-class Cranfield University in my constituency. They told me how robotic technology is developing and highlighted the challenges that lie ahead. We discussed rapid changes in the workplace with more automation, safety issues as people work more closely with robots, and the ethics of self-learning robots. I have seen at first hand the speed this sector is moving, and as technology moves quickly it is important that legislation keeps up, which is why I voted in favour of today’s report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: –  Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank rapporteur Mady Delvaux for her excellent report. We in the European Parliament have started a very important discussion, a discussion of the future of mankind. Robots will play a significant role in our future life, and we have to start to think about the important elements of this new reality. A central part of this report is the issue of liability. The civil liability for damage caused by robots is a crucial issue which needs to be analysed and addressed at Union level as soon as it possible. The Commission has to carry out an impact assessment for a compulsory insurance scheme which includes the possibility of giving the legal status of an electronic personality to robots, in order to facilitate compensation for victims when human responsibility cannot be fully attributed. It is vitally important for the legislature to consider the legal and ethical implications and effects without stifling innovation, and of course I voted in favour.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President, surely no one doubts that we are witnessing a new industrial revolution. Every day we read about great advances in robotics, which can make us feel like we've already started living in the age of sci-fi movies. Such progress brings incredible opportunities for humanity to improve life. But sometimes it's just so apparent. On the other hand, this area raises, opens up a large number of questions and risks. In many cases, machines are already replacing people in the work process. In fact, no one knows what a fully robotic labor market will look like. According to the OECD, the Slovak Republic is the second most endangered economy in this respect in terms of rising unemployment. It is also dangerous for transhumanism to become law. Human rights belong sovereignly to man. Attributing them to artificial intelligence is completely against the natural creative order. I am afraid of the consequences of such an action. The resolution does not provide answers, but only brings more confusion to the subject. All the multinationals and scientists behind robotization need to take responsibility for this development, and it is essential to guarantee that man's decision is to blame.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, more than € 450 billion has been allocated to structural and investment funds for the period 2014-2020. Cohesion policy is still perceived as an expenditure policy, although it is, in fact, a development and investment policy. For example, in Romania, with this money we must encourage SMEs, support research, innovation, create and diversify jobs, develop infrastructure, we must also invest this money in geographically disadvantaged areas or at the border poverty. I am pleased that an important goal of the Commission for 2014-2020 is to continue simplifications for the beneficiaries of the Structural and Investment Funds. Simplification is very important because access to these funds is easier, as is controlling the way money is used. Other key factors are the interest, transparency and competence of the central and local authorities that manage this money.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, having been on the Regional Development Committee in the last legislature, I saw how difficult this topic was, and how hard people like Mr Van Nistelrooij and Mr Albrecht worked and became experts in the field. When they say something one should listen, as they know what they are talking about. One of the points I want to highlight here is their comment on visibility. Given that 30% or more of our budget goes in cohesion funding and that in many Member States 60% to 80% of public investment comes from the European Union, I wonder whether the people who are benefiting from it know of it? Indeed, I heard in relation to Brexit that some people who voted against were actually being employed and being paid by European funds but did not even know it. So from here on, with money that is spent in cohesion funding there must also be absolute certainty that this is communicated to those who benefit and to the public.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I chose not to support the vote on Aviation Strategy for Europe today, 16 February 2017. As part of its Brexit strategy for the United Kingdom, the country is pushing ahead with its own agenda for aviation with the ‘Sky’s the Limit’ Coalition, representing airlines and airports. UK Air Traffic Control has welcomed the publication of the UK Government’s airspace and noise policy as a first step towards modernising United Kingdom airspace – including, I might add, that for drones. In contrast, the European Union strategy is beset with problems associated with fulfilling aspects relating to other European Union policies, not least emission limitations. I could not support a strategy which would prove a drag anchor on the United Kingdom’s lead in this critical area of expertise.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.(The sitting was closed at 1.15 p. M.)
